meta.title: Age Requirements & Accessibility - Hostel Brikette, Positano Guide
meta.description: Discover age restrictions, accessibility details, self-sufficiency policies, minors guidelines, amenities, transport tips, house rules, and sustainability practices at the only hostel in Positano.

content.accessibilityRequirements: Set into the steep, postcard-perfect cliffs for which Positano is world-famous, Hostel Brikette occupies a lovingly developed nineteenth-century residence that was never designed with modern elevators or ramps. Reaching reception requires climbing approximately 30 outdoor stone steps from the nearest pedestrian lane, and most dormitories are a further one or two internal flights above that level. As a hostel, we do not have a conceirge service, so you will need to plan around carrying your bags youself.
content.arrivalByFerry: The port is some distance from the hostel.  Whilst it can be nice to arrive by ferry, you will need to plan to get to the hostel.  We do not recommend doing so on foot, with any substantial luggage or baggage, particularly in the summer.  We recommend using Positano's registered porter services, who will bring your things direct to the hostel for you. We also recommend using the local bus service. You can get directions, along with many other useful tips, via our app, which you will receive access to when you book.
content.arrivalByBus: The closest bus stop to us is 100m/300ft away.  It is flat between us and the bus stop, so you just need to plan on getting your things from the street to your room.
content.generalArrivalTips: For reasons set out above, we advise packing light, using backpacks rather than wheeled suitcases, and wearing sensible shoes with grip.
content.reducedMobility: If you have reduced mobility, a visual impairment, or rely on assistive devices, please email us in advance so that we can describe the layout in detail and help you assess whether the area and the hostel's building meets your personal requirements.
content.serviceAnimals: Please note that we can only host certified service animals in private rooms only, subject to prior arrangement and national regulations.
content.assistedSleeping: To preserve a restful atmosphere in shared spaces, devices that create continuous or intermittent sound - such as CPAP machines, white-noise generators, meditation speakers, or talking clocks - may be used only when a private room has been booked.
content.selfSufficiencyPolicy: In keeping with the independent spirit of backpacking, we operate on a self-catering, self-service basis. Our small team is always happy to help, but we are not doctors, pharmacists, nurses, or professional caregivers, and cannot legally store or administer prescription medication. All guests must be able to carry their own luggage, climb the stairs described above, check themselves in and out, manage personal hygiene, and interact in social spaces, without staff intervention.
content.essentialMedicine: If you travel with essential medication that requires refrigeration, we can store that for you; please email us before arrival to reserve space. The nearest pharmacy is 450 m away on Viale Pasitea and the closest public medical clinic is in Praiano, 3 km by bus. Should a health emergency occur, staff will immediately contact Italian emergency services (dial 118), but we cannot, ourselves, provide professional medical assistance on site. If during your stay it becomes apparent that you are unable to meet these minimum self-sufficiency standards, management reserves the right to terminate your reservation in accordance with Article 1382 of the Italian Civil Code. Any unused nights will be refunded minus the first night and card processing fees.
content.minorsPolicy: Italian hospitality regulations are particularly clear when it comes to protecting young travellers, which we fully support. Children aged 16 and under may stay only in private rooms, when accompanied by a parent or legal guardian who is at least 18 years old, and who sleeps in the same room for the entire stay. School, sports, or scout groups under 18 must book the entire property or arrange exclusive room occupancy, and must provide a signed declaration of responsibility on official letterhead from the organising institution at least seven days before arrival. For guests who are 17 years old, mixed-gender or single-gender dormitories may be booked, provided that a supervising adult aged 18+ occupies a bed in the same dorm and submits - on arrival - either a notarised parental consent form or documented proof of guardianship. Under no circumstances can minors be left unattended in common areas. Failure to comply with the above rules will result in immediate cancellation without refund, and, where relevant, notification of local authorities as required by Italian public-safety law (Consolidated Text of Public Security, Article 109).
content.locationOverview: We are located within 100m/300ft of the nearest main line bus stop, and the local bus stop. Grocery stores, an ATM/cashpoint, restaurants, and a small electronics store are also located very close to the hostel. We have a very good position for day trips and local conveniences. Positano's tourist center, beaches, and ferry port is located further away. You can get into this area using the local bus.
content.transportationGuide: Reaching Positano and Hostel Brikette from Naples International Airport (Capodichino) you can take the Curreri Viaggi shuttle to Sorrento Circumvesuviana station, then hop on the SITA Sud bus toward Amalfi, disembarking at the “Positano Chiesa Nuova” stop. We provide very detailed guides on getting to the hostel, to help you plan your trip here. We recommend reading them, as it can help save you time and effort on your journey.  Seasonal ferries will drop you off at Positano port, but note that you will want to plan carefully for getting from the port to the hostel. Arriving by car is possible but not recommended: historic-centre parking is extremely limited and costs upward of €45 per day. If you really want to drive, pre-book a space at Garage Mandara and plan to unload luggage at the hostel before going to part.

meta.title: Booking Basics: Your Essential Guide to Staying at Hostel Brikette, Positano - the Only Hostel in Positano
meta.description: Discover everything you need to know before you book the only hostel in Positano, on Italy's Amalfi Coast. Learn about secure payments, flexible and non-refundable bookings, check-in rules, cancellation policies, and insider tips for an unforgettable stay in Positano's only hostel.

content.aboutOurHostel: Skylar SRL proudly operates Hostel Brikette, Positano - the only hostel in Positano. You'll find us at Via Guglielmo Marconi 358, 84017 Positano, Salerno, Italy. We are perfectly located for the Amalfi Coast, being central to Amalfi, Ravello, Sorrento, and the island of Capri - making us perfect not just for Positano but also day trips to each of those places. From our panoramic terrace, you will be surrounded by mountains, and have great views of the famous limestone cliffs as they plunge into the sea below. If you're searching for affordability, social atmosphere, unbeatable views, great service, then check out Hostel Brikette.
content.termsAndConditions: Our terms and conditions are transparent, concise, and designed to protect both you and us. They outline essential details like payment schedules, security deposit rules, quiet-hour policies, and guest-only access to dormitories. The terms and conditions are aligned with Italian tourism legislation and standard hostel practices across Europe. We strongly encourage all guests to familiarise themselves with these terms before arriving so that there are no surprises after check-in. By completing your booking, you acknowledge that you have read, understood, and accepted Hostel Brikette's Terms & Conditions,
content.youCustomerGuest: This booking guide aims to help every guest who either stays overnight or interacts with the hostel on someone else's behalf. Whether you are a solo backpacker, a digital nomad, a couple on a romantic getaway, a group leader coordinating a school trip, or simply a temporary visitor dropping by to enjoy the terrace, these guidelines ensure that everyone is treated fairly and the hostel operates smoothly.
content.roomBookingRequest: Booking your stay at Hostel Brikette is quick and secure. You can reserve directly on this website for the best rates, flexible policies, and to gain access to complimentary breakfast and evening drinks. You can also book to stay at the hostel through trusted online travel agencies (OTAs) such as Hostelworld and Booking.com.
content.onlyHostelPositano: Hostel Brikette is Positano's only hostel. Book directly or contact us to ensure you make a valid booking at our hostel. Please also note that unauthorised resale or transfer of bookings is strictly prohibited and will result in immediate cancellation without refund.
content.communalAreas: Our communal areas are designed for social interaction and unrivalled Mediterranean vistas. Enjoy morning cappuccinos on our terrace, join sunset aperitivo hour overlooking Positano's bay area, or catch up on remote work in beautiful lobby equipped with free Wi-Fi. We also provide spacious, gender-segregated communal bathrooms with hot-water available 24/7. Temporary visitors may share these areas during visiting hours, as long as they present valid ID at reception.
content.creditCardHolder: The credit-card holder - the person whose name appears on the card used to secure the booking - is ultimately responsible for all accommodation charges, add-ons, and penalties incurred. If you are booking on behalf of someone else, please ensure you have written permission from the card holder, or contact us so we can arrange a secure third-party payment link.
content.counteroffer: In high-demand periods such as June to September, certain room types may sell out fast. If your preferred dorm bed or private room is unavailable, we'll promptly send you a friendly counter-offer suggesting alternative dates or room categories. Feel free to accept, reject, or negotiate - our team is all based here in the Amalfi Coast and will help you lock in the ideal hostel experience.
content.confirmedRoomBooking: Your reservation is considered confirmed the instant you receive our automated confirmation email. This document details your booking reference, arrival date, number of nights, bed type (mixed dorm, female-only dorm, or private room), and total cost. Keep this email handy - you'll need to show it at check-in if your surname doesn't match the booking name.
content.noShow: A "no-show" occurs when a guest fails to arrive and complete check-in by 22:00 (local time) on the scheduled arrival date. To protect our small, independent business from lost revenue, no-shows are charged the full first night or the entire non-refundable balance, whichever amount is greater. If you anticipate a late arrival, simply email us before 21:00 so we can arrange a late self-check-in kit.
content.roomCancellationRequest: Plans change - we get it! If you must cancel your stay in Positano, please notify us as early as possible by emailing hostelpositano@gmail.com. Early cancellations free up beds for other backpackers exploring the Amalfi Coast and may reduce or eliminate any applicable fees for you.
content.cancellationNoticePeriod: Unless otherwise stated on your rate plan, a standard 72-hour cancellation policy applies. This means you must cancel by 15:00, three full days before your arrival date, to avoid charges. Non-refundable or "early bird" discounted rates may have different terms, so always check your confirmation email for specifics.
content.cancellationAdministrationFee: A small €5 administration fee per booking may apply to cover transaction costs associated with processing refunds and updating inventory across multiple booking platforms. This fee is clearly displayed at the time of reservation and reiterated in your confirmation email.
content.hostelOfficialEmail: For any official correspondence - whether it's a special request, group inquiry, or visa confirmation letter - write to our dedicated inbox at hostelpositano@gmail.com. We answer emails daily from 08:00 to 22:00.
content.bookingChangeRequest: Need to move your booking forward a week, add another traveller, or upgrade to a sea-view private? Send your request by email using the subject line "Booking Change - [Your Surname, Arrival Date]." Changes are subject to availability but we always do our best to keep guests happy and flexibility high.
content.designatedEmailAddress: A valid email address is mandatory at the time of booking because it is how we send confirmation that you have booked to stay with us at Hostel Brikette. If you do not receive an email within ten minutes of booking, please check your spam folder and mark us as a safe sender. We also send access to an application that you can use to plan your travel, time whilst you are at the hostel, place orders for food and drink, and so on. This application is very helpful, and will ensure you get the most of your time at Hostel Brikette, in Positano and along the Amalfi Coast.
content.bookingExtensionRequest: Once you've experienced Positano's cliffside charm, you may decide you never want to leave. No problem - email or speak to reception about extending your stay. Extra nights are granted on a first-come, first-serve basis, so let us know early, especially during the peak Amalfi Coast season.
content.checkInRequest: Check-in runs daily from 15:00 to 22:00. If you reach Positano before room time, we'll store your luggage for free (we can store luggage from 10:30am, daily), so you can head straight to Spiaggia Grande, the Sentiero degli Dei hiking trail, grab a bite to eat, etc. Please have your passport or ID ready for a swift registration.
content.assignedRoom: During check-in we'll assign you a bed or private room best suited to your reservation type and group size. Housekeeping prepares rooms between 10:30 and 15:00, so earlier access cannot always be guaranteed; however, our terrace are available if you'd like to freshen up immediately after arrival.
content.hostelRooms: Choose among accommodation categories: 4-bed, 6-bed, 7-bed, and 8-bed dorms.  Whether you want a mixed bed or female-only room.  We have rooms with and without views.  We have a private double with en-suite. All dorms have secure lockers, reading lights, USB charging ports, WiFi, and air-conditioning.
content.linen: Each guest receives freshly laundered cotton sheets, a comfy pillow, and a bath towel. For ecological reasons, we change linens every fourth night of extended stays. Additional towels are available for a small fee - just ask at reception.
content.roomUpgrade: Occasionally, we surprise lucky guests with a complimentary upgrade, but we do cannot guarantee to do so, nor do we have a rewards scheme or such which promotes an upgrade chance.  Whilst paid upgrade might be possible, during peak summer months, and possibly at other busy times, it might not be possible. We recommend booking the room you want to ensure you get what you are looking for.
content.keycard: We issue RFID keycards at check-in, on 10 euros deposit.  The keycard grants 24-hour access to your specific room. Lost cards incur a €10 replacement fee, so please keep yours safe. Remember to return your keycard at check-out, so that we can refund your deposit.
content.preauthorization: To secure your spot, we may perform a temporary pre-authorisation on your card equal to the cost of the first night. This hold is released automatically by your bank within a few days, depending on their policies. It is not a debit - simply a guarantee that you intend to enjoy your stay at Hostel Brikette.
content.checkout: Check-out time is 10:30am, giving our housekeeping team enough time to prepare rooms for incoming travellers. Before leaving, strip your bed, return your linens and keycard, and pick up any belongings from communal areas or the luggage room. Luggage storage after check-out is free until 15:30pm.
content.minor: Under Italian law, anyone under 18 must present a notarised parental consent form if travelling without a legal guardian. Minors are only permitted in private rooms, and may not share mixed dormitories with unrelated adults.
content.complimentaryService: If you book directly with Hostel Brikette, we can provide complimentary perks to stretch your budget: a quality breakfast and evening drinks.  All guests may receive complimentary Wi-Fi throughout the property, use of a communal fridge to store snacks, and luggage storage before check-in or after check-out. These services are complimentary, and subject to terms and conditions.
content.temporaryGuest: We understand that friends and travel companions staying elsewhere may want to visit you. Temporary guests might be allowed to visit, in the lobby and terrace, between 10:30am and 20:00pm.  We need any temporary visitors to sign-in at reception with valid ID. We may decline to host temporary visitors for any reason, including that we need to ensure the safety and security of guests. Overnight stays without a booking are not permitted.
content.acceptedPaymentMethods: We accept Visa and Mastercard credit or debit cards, as well as cash in euros. Corporations and universities organising group trips can pay via bank transfer by prior arrangement. Unfortunately, we do not accept American Express or cryptocurrency at this time.
content.prepaidNonRefundableBookings: Pre-paid, non-refundable bookings lock in the lowest available price for your chosen dates. The total amount is charged immediately after reservation and cannot be refunded under any circumstances, even in the event of travel disruptions. This rate is ideal for travellers who are 100 % certain of their itinerary and wish to secure a bed in Positano's only hostel during the busy summer months.
content.firstComeFirstToChoose: Dormitory bunks operate on a first-come, first-choose basis, allowing early arrivals the privilege of selecting top or bottom bunks. If you have mobility concerns and require a lower bunk, please note that we cannot guarantee that you will get one.
content.refundableBookings: Flexible, refundable bookings offer peace of mind to travellers with uncertain schedules. Pay only a small deposit today and settle the balance on arrival. Cancellations within the permitted window incur no additional charge, and date changes are usually possible subject to availability.
content.proofOfIdentity: Italian law requires us to register every guest with local authorities. Acceptable forms of ID include passport (recommended), EU national identity card, valid driver's licence, or military ID. Photocopies are not accepted. Failure to produce ID may result in denied check-in without refund.
content.seriousDefect: Your comfort and safety are our top priorities. If you find any defect - from a flickering reading light to a leaky shower - alert reception immediately. We will either fix the issue on the spot or relocate you to another bed or room of equal value.
content.ota: While booking directly guarantees the best price and flexibility, we proudly partner with Hostelworld, Booking.com, and other OTAs so you can read thousands of verified traveller reviews before deciding to stay at Hostel Brikette - the top-rated, only hostel on Italy's legendary Amalfi Coast.

meta.title: Changing and Cancelling Your Positano Hostel Reservation
meta.description: Detailed guidance on your cancellation options, no-show policies, how to modify your reservation, booking transfer rules, and pre-paid non-refundable bookings at Positano's only hostel.

content.noShowCharges: If you haven't checked in by 22:30 (10:30 PM) on the first day of your reservation, your booking will automatically be marked as a 'No-Show.' You will be charged the higher of either the first night's stay or your non-refundable deposit. If you hold multiple bookings, each one may carry its own cancellation notice period and fees.
content.cancellationsPolicy: Send all cancellation requests in writing to our official email address (hostelpositano@gmail.com). The cancellation period begins when the hostel receives your email and ends at 00:01 on your scheduled check-in date. Your booking remains active until you receive email confirmation that the cancellation has been processed. A separate Cancellation Administration Fee—usually 15% of the booking price excluding third-party commissions—will be charged. The hostel may cancel your booking without a written request if you fail to check in before reception closes on arrival day, depart early without proper notification, or violate hostel policies. If you do not provide sufficient notice, you will incur charges equivalent to a No-Show.
content.changingConfirmedBookings: Existing reservations cannot be directly modified; instead, they are replaced entirely with new bookings. Email your change request to our official email address within the required notice period. You will receive an email once the change is approved. All changes are subject to room availability and other conditions. If you shorten or extend your stay, the adjustment will be handled as a cancellation or extension request, and any extension is treated as a new reservation. If you leave before your confirmed departure date without receiving an official cancellation confirmation, the original booking terms will remain in effect.
content.bookingTransferability: Your booking must stay under your name for the entire stay. Transferring the reservation or changing the guest name is not allowed. If someone attempts to check in under a transferred booking, the reservation will be canceled immediately, and you will remain financially responsible for the full amount.
content.prepaidNonRefundableBookings: Pre-paid, Non-Refundable reservations require full payment at the time of booking. If the payment does not go through, your reservation will be canceled automatically. These bookings are not refundable, even if you cancel or do not show up. Any extension to your stay will be processed as a separate, new non-refundable booking.

meta.title: Complete Check-in & Checkout Guide for Hostel Brikette Positano
meta.description: Step-by-step instructions on arrival times, ID requirements, luggage storage, deposits, and checkout support at Hostel Brikette in Positano.

content.checkInRequest: When you arrive, please visit our reception desk to start your check-in process and receive your room assignment.
content.earlyArrival: If you arrive before 10:30 AM on your booking date, please note that you will not yet be able to enter the hostel.
content.middayArrival: If you arrive between 10:30 AM and 3:00 PM, you may be allowed entry as a Temporary Guest, pending approval. During this time, you may request luggage storage, provided space is available. Please note luggage storage is separate from your room booking and has its own terms and conditions.
content.checkInWindow: You can check in from 3:00 PM to 10:30 PM daily. During this time, you'll follow our standard check-in process.
content.lateArrival: If you plan to arrive after our reception closes at 10:30 PM, we may offer you a self-service late check-in option, subject to availability. We will send instructions to the contact details you provided during booking. Make sure your device is charged and your details are correct, as we cannot be responsible for issues caused by incorrect information or technical failures.
content.necessityOfProcess: You must complete the full check-in procedure to enter the hostel. If you cannot complete check-in, your reservation will be canceled and treated as a No Show.
content.proofOfIdentity: You must present a valid original form of identification (passport, national ID card, driver's license, or military ID) upon arrival. If you do not provide valid ID by 10:30 PM on your scheduled check-in day, your reservation will be canceled as a No Show.
content.paymentBalance: You must fully settle any outstanding balance using an Accepted Payment Method before completing check-in. If you cannot make the full payment, your reservation will be canceled and marked as a No Show.
content.keycardLinenDeposit: At check-in, you'll need to provide a €10 cash deposit for your keycard and linen set. This deposit will be fully refunded in cash upon checkout once you return both items. Credit or debit cards cannot be accepted for this deposit.
content.checkoutWindow: Checkout is from 7:30 AM to 10:30 AM. After checkout, you cannot re-enter your room or leave any personal belongings behind.
content.earlyCheckout: If you need to depart before 7:30 AM, please arrange early checkout at reception the evening before to receive your deposit refund in cash. Leaving your keycard without staff confirmation will result in forfeiture of the deposit.
content.lateCheckout: We cannot provide late checkout. Checkout should be complete by 10:30am.
content.failureToCheckout: If you don't vacate your room by the official checkout time, we may remove your belongings without liability. Your items could be stored with a local porter service at your expense. Any unauthorized entry afterward will be treated as a security breach.
content.postCheckout: Once you checkout, your reservation officially ends. You may remain on the hostel premises as a Temporary Guest until 3:30 PM. You can request luggage storage, subject to availability and separate conditions.

meta.title: Defects and Damages Guide for Positano Hostel
meta.description: Understand how to report room defects, our response to serious issues, damage deposit policies, guest liability, and essential information on bed-bug prevention at Positano's exclusive hostel.

content.reportingDefects: If you notice any issue or defect in your room, please inform us immediately. Your prompt notification helps us quickly address and resolve the problem.
content.assessingDefects: Once you report a defect, we'll assess the issue promptly and prioritize our response based on how significantly it impacts your comfort and stay.
content.responseToSeriousDefects: If there's a serious defect that cannot be immediately repaired, we'll provide alternative accommodation. If the alternative is cheaper than your booked room, we'll refund you the price difference. If you decide not to accept our alternative, you can request a pro-rata refund for the remaining nights of your stay.
content.unreportedDefects: If we discover an issue in your room that you haven't reported within a reasonable timeframe, we will evaluate any resulting damages, and our damage policy may be applied.
content.damagesPolicy: For your security and ours, we may pre-authorize your credit card or request a cash deposit at check-in to cover potential damages or losses. If you cannot provide a deposit or pre-authorization, your reservation may be canceled. Deposits are fully refundable at checkout, minus charges for any damages, losses, labour, or administrative expenses incurred. If these charges exceed your deposit, you will be responsible for the additional costs. Labour rates for repairs or cleanup are billed hourly: Director (€50/hour), Manager (€35/hour), and Staff (€25/hour).
content.bedBugsPolicy: We proactively manage and promptly address any bed-bug issues. However, if bed bugs are found in your room during your stay, you may be held responsible for associated costs, such as lost booking revenue, cleaning expenses, and pest control. Please immediately report any bed-bug signs to our staff.
content.bedBugsPrevention:
To help prevent bed-bug issues, please:
• Inform us at check-in if you've recently stayed somewhere with known bed-bug problems.
• Thoroughly disinfect your belongings.
• Carefully inspect your luggage and clothing for bed bugs before entering your room.

content.submittingBookingRequest: Send us your booking request through an authorised Online Travel Agent (OTA) or directly on our website — chats or walk-ins alone don't count. By clicking 'Book', you confirm that all names, dates, and stay length are correct and that you accept our Terms & Conditions.
content.processingBookingRequest: We start processing your request as soon as we successfully receive any required deposit, pre-authorisation, or payment using one of our accepted payment methods. Make sure the booking shows the name of the credit-card holder who will pay. If the payer's name is different, email us a short authorisation from the cardholder before we process your request.
content.decliningBookingRequest: We rarely decline a booking, but we reserve the right to do so at our discretion — for example, if payment fails, required information is missing, or the request breaches our Terms & Conditions.
content.requestSizeLimit: One booking request can cover up to seven (7) consecutive nights and a maximum of five (5) guests. Need a longer stay or a bigger group? Simply split it into separate requests.
content.counterOffer: If your preferred room is already taken, we'll email you a counter-offer with the closest alternative. Accept the offer and complete the payment or pre-authorisation to lock in your stay.
content.prepaidNonRefundableBookingsPolicy: Choosing a Pre-paid Non-Refundable rate saves you money but requires full payment upfront. We'll try your card up to three times. If all attempts fail, we'll cancel the request. These bookings cannot be refunded or modified.
content.confirmationEmail: Once your payment clears, we'll send a confirmation email to the address you gave us. It lists your booking reference, arrival date, length of stay, and any extras. Read it carefully and tell us immediately if anything looks wrong.
content.numberOfGuestsIncluded:
Your booking automatically covers the following:
• 1 guest per single bed
• Up to 2 guests per double bed
• Up to the advertised capacity of any apartment you book
For safety and comfort we can't accommodate extra guests above the room's limit.
content.scopeOfFacilitiesIncluded:
Every guest receives:
• Fresh linen and a keycard
• Use of the shared showers
• Hot water during scheduled hours (about 07:00-10:30 and 17:00-22:30)
• Access to our communal areas
Other perks (breakfast, Wi-Fi, luggage storage, etc.) are complimentary and follow their own simple rules.
content.financialObligation: The credit-card holder named on your booking is liable for all charges — room fees, damages, cleaning fees, fines, or penalties for breaking house rules. Unpaid amounts may be charged directly to the card on file.
content.roomAllocation: We guarantee you the bed type and room category you booked. Dorm bookings secure a bed in the chosen category, but we can't promise that groups will share the same room. Beds in dorms are chosen first-come, first-served when you check in.
content.allocatingUpgrades: Sometimes we upgrade you to a better room free of charge, or you can pay to upgrade when you book. If the free upgrade later becomes impractical, we may move you back to the category you originally paid for.
content.thirdPartyPayments: When you book through an OTA, you'll pay through their system under their terms. We never see your card details from the OTA and aren't liable for issues on their platform. Always check that your payment went through and that you received a confirmation.
content.bookingRequestDeposits: Some rates need a deposit to hold the room. Pre-paid rates require 100% up-front. Deposits are non-refundable. If we can't take the deposit, the booking request is automatically cancelled.
content.bookingRequestPreauthorisations: For flexible rates we may pre-authorise your card for the first night or the full stay to guarantee your booking. If the pre-authorisation fails, we'll decline the request.
content.safeguardingProcess: When you check in, we may place a security hold equal to one night per guest to cover possible fines, fees, extensions, or damages. If a card hold isn't possible, you can leave the same amount in cash or use another guest's card. If neither option works, we unfortunately have to cancel your booking.

meta.title: Hostel Rules and Policies - Positano Hostel
meta.description: Read and follow our core house rules—including our no-outside-alcohol policy and duty-of-care guidelines—to keep everyone safe and ensure you have an enjoyable stay.

content.alcoholPolicy: Because we are a licensed venue, you may not bring or consume alcohol bought off-site anywhere on hostel property. If you arrive with outside alcohol, our team will store it safely and return it at checkout (or once you confirm it will be consumed off-site). Our team's decision on this is final. Bringing or drinking outside alcohol will cancel your booking on the spot, be treated as a No-Show, and no refund will be issued.
content.dutyOfCare:
While you are with us, you share the hostel with other guests, staff, and contractors. Please:
• Respect everyone's privacy and personal space.
• Take care not to damage hostel or guest property.
• Keep noise to a reasonable level and help maintain a calm, friendly atmosphere.
• Follow any additional rules or instructions given by our staff.
If you ignore these duties, we may cancel your booking immediately (recorded as a No-Show), ask you to leave without refund, and hold you financially responsible for fines, legal costs, reputational damage, or any other expense. intro: Make the most of a day in Amalfi town: key sights, how to get there, and timing tips to beat tour-bus crowds.

sections.title: Top sights
body: Climb the 62 steps to Amalfi Cathedral for the striped facade, cloister, and museum (modest dress required).
Visit the Museo della Carta to see hand-made paper demonstrations and bring home lightweight souvenirs.

sections.title: Getting there
body: Ferries from Positano take 20 minutes; buses take 40–50 minutes depending on traffic. Arrive before 10:00 to snag shade on the piazza.
Buy return ferry tickets early afternoon in case sailings adjust for wind.

sections.title: When to go
body: Mornings (before 11:00) or evenings (after 17:00) are quietest once day-trippers depart.
Pair Amalfi with Atrani (five-minute walk) for dinner on the smaller piazza before heading back.

tips: Pack a lightweight scarf for church visits and to block sun on the ferry ride.
Grab lemon granita from the waterfront kiosks to cool down between stops.

faqs.q: How long do I need in Amalfi?
a: Allow three to four hours to cover the cathedral, paper museum, and a relaxed meal. Add extra time if you plan to swim at the small town beach.

faqs.q: Are there luggage storage options?
a: Yes, luggage deposits sit near the ferry pier. Expect €5–€8 per bag for the day.

seo.title: Arienzo Beach Guide
seo.description: Reserve loungers, choose the shuttle boat or 300-step stairway, and plan food and transport for Arienzo Beach.

intro: Arienzo sits just east of Positano with long afternoon sun, turquoise water, and a dramatic stairway down from the Amalfi Coast road. It is the liveliest lido within easy reach of Hostel Brikette, but between the stairs and reservation-only policies you want a plan before you set off.
Use this guide to lock in your spot, choose whether to ride the shuttle boat or walk the 300 steps, and budget for lunch, drinks, and the ride home.

sections.title: Why Arienzo works for Hostel Brikette guests
body: Arienzo is the closest full-service beach club outside the crush of Spiaggia Grande. The cliffside terraces catch sunlight until early evening, the water stays clear for swimming, and the bar keeps the party atmosphere without tipping into nightlife territory.

You can split your group between packages that include loungers and lunch or reserve a front-row deck for a splurge day. With some planning you dodge queues and still be back at the hostel before sunset drinks on the terrace.

sections.title: Getting there: shuttle boat or 300 steps
body: The easiest route is the Arienzo Beach Club shuttle boat that departs from Spiaggia Grande. Boats run roughly every 30 minutes from 09:30, with the last outbound ride around 13:30. Your reservation confirmation includes a QR code—show it on the dock and keep the return schedule handy.

Walking is possible if you prefer to avoid the boat. Take the SITA bus towards Amalfi (board at the Sponda stop 10 minutes downhill from the hostel) and hop off at the signed Arienzo stop. From there descend 300 stairs through lemon terraces to reach the club entrance.
Arriving by car or scooter is discouraged; parking is extremely limited and traffic police fine vehicles that block the bends.

sections.title: Layout and beach operators
body: The main deck belongs to Arienzo Beach Club with orange loungers, towel service, freshwater showers, and a lively bar. A smaller free strip sits on the far right near the boat landing, but space disappears after 10:30 and you still need to manage the stairs with all your gear.
Sun reaches the first two rows until roughly 17:30 in summer before the cliffs cast shade. Ask staff to angle umbrellas as the light shifts, especially if you prefer a full day of tanning.
Freshwater showers, lockers, and changing cabins are included with the day packages. Wi-Fi is patchy; download playlists or ferry updates before you arrive.

sections.title: Packages, dining, and reservations
body: Standard day beds start around €70 for two people and include umbrella, towels, two welcome drinks, and the shuttle boat. Front-row platforms and prestige cabanas push €120–€200 depending on the month.
Lunch is served from 12:30 with seafood pasta, salads, and grilled mains. Expect €18–€28 per dish; reserve a table when you check in to avoid the 14:00 rush.

Bookings are handled directly through Arienzo’s website or by messaging their WhatsApp line. Payment details secure your spot; cancellations within 48 hours usually incur a fee, so confirm the weather forecast and ferry plans first.

sections.title: Heading back to Hostel Brikette
body: Return boats leave Arienzo on the half hour starting around 15:00; the final shuttle normally departs at 18:00 but times shift during shoulder season—double-check the board near reception.

If you walked down, allow 15–20 minutes to climb the stairs to the road. Buses towards Positano pass every 30–40 minutes in the afternoon; validate your ticket on board and have a spare for late returns.
Need a night swim? Pre-arrange a taxi pick-up through reception or the digital concierge, as ride-hailing apps do not operate reliably along the coast.

essentials: Mandatory reservations in peak season—book online or via WhatsApp before leaving the hostel.
Choose between the shuttle boat from Spiaggia Grande or the 300-step stairway from the SITA bus stop.
Full-service lido with bar, restaurant, showers, and towel service included in day packages.
typicalCosts: Day bed for two with shuttle boat: €70–€90 depending on season.
Front-row platform or cabana: €120–€200 for two guests.
Lunch mains: €18–€28, cocktails €12–€15, bottled water €3–€4.
tips: %LINK:hostelBriketteToArienzoBus|Getting to the beach by bus%.
%LINK:arienzoBeachBusBack|Getting back from the beach by bus%.
Screenshot your booking confirmation; mobile signal fades along the stairway and at the dock.
Pack a reusable water bottle—refills are available at the bar and keep costs down on hot days.
Compare other coastal options in our %LINK:positanoBeaches|beaches overview% if you want a quieter or free alternative.
warnings: No cash refunds for late arrivals; call ahead if you are running behind so staff can hold your loungers.
The free section is extremely small and still requires navigating the full staircase with your gear.
Wave conditions occasionally pause the shuttle boat—staff will text updates, but have the bus plan ready.

faqs.q: How far in advance should I reserve?
a: Book at least three to five days ahead in June–September, especially for weekend slots or front-row platforms. Shoulder season (April, May, October) often has next-day availability but still confirm the shuttle schedule.

faqs.q: Can I visit without buying a package?
a: Yes, but options are limited. A small public strip sits beside the club and fills by mid-morning. You will not have access to bathrooms or showers without a package, and you must still manage the long stairway.

faqs.q: What should I wear for the stair climb?
a: Wear sturdy sandals or trainers for the descent. Carry heavier items in a backpack and pause at the midway landings. On the way back up, take breaks in the shade and hydrate before boarding the bus or taxi.

seo.title: Art and Artisans of Positano (shopping)
seo.description: Sandals, ceramics, prints — where to find quality and how to ship.

intro: Shop Positano's artisan scene without overpaying: sandals, ceramics, prints, and how to ship items home.

sections.title: Custom sandals
body: Watch cobblers handcraft leather sandals in 30 minutes; prices start around €80 for bespoke pairs.
Bring or trace your foot for remote orders later—many artisans ship worldwide once they have your measurements.

sections.title: Ceramics & art
body: Browse family-run ceramic studios for hand-painted tiles and tableware. Ask about lead-free glazes if you plan to serve food.
Local artists sell prints and watercolours along Via Cristoforo Colombo—tube packaging protects them for travel.

sections.title: Paying & shipping
body: Most shops accept cards but offer cash discounts. Keep ID handy for tax refund paperwork on purchases over €154.94.
Ship fragile pieces via insured courier (DHL/UPS) and ask for double boxing; rates start around €40 depending on weight.

tips: Photograph receipts and artisan details so you remember which studio crafted each item.
Pack bubble wrap if you plan to carry ceramics in your luggage—hostels often have spare padding from deliveries.

faqs.q: Can artisans personalise items?
a: Yes. Many will emboss initials on sandals or customise ceramic colours with a few days' notice.

faqs.q: How do I claim a VAT refund?
a: Request a tax-free form at purchase, have it stamped at the airport or ferry port, and submit within three months for reimbursement.

seo.title: How to avoid crowds in Positano (off the beaten path)
seo.description: Timing, quiet routes, alternative towns, and smart photo spots to enjoy Positano without the queues.

avoidCrowdsPositano.linkLabel: How to avoid crowds in Positano (off the beaten path)
intro: Avoiding crowds in Positano means timing your outings, weaving through lesser-used lanes, and knowing when to hop to a quieter town.

sections.title: Timing that works
body: Arrive at Spiaggia Grande or the main viewpoints around sunrise or golden hour; late lunches (after 14:30) also dodge peak seating demand.
Pause midday for shade or a siesta—most day-trippers fill the lanes between 10:00 and 16:00.

sections.title: Routes & quieter spots
body: Use the upper walkway between Chiesa Nuova and Sponda for balcony views without the Via dei Mulini bottleneck.
Head to Fornillo Beach or the Via Positanesi d’America overlook for calmer swims and photos.

sections.title: Alternative bases
body: Praiano and Cetara offer slower evenings, easy sunset spots, and cheaper meals without losing coastal views.
Ravello’s gardens or Agerola’s hill villages make good day escapes when Positano feels saturated.

faqs.q: When is Spiaggia Grande quiet?
a: Before 09:00 or after 18:30 you’ll find space to sit and softer light for photos—pack a towel and arrive early.

faqs.q: Where can I shoot photos without crowds?
a: Walk up Via Cristoforo Colombo for elevated terraces or take the bus to Nocelle for wide Path of the Gods panoramas.

faqs.q: Should I stay outside Positano for quieter nights?
a: Yes if you prefer calmer evenings—Praiano, Minori, or Agerola keep prices lower and you can bus or ferry into Positano by day.

seo.title: Positano on a backpacker budget: 1-3 day itineraries
seo.description: Simple 1-3 day plans with beaches, viewpoints, and low-cost day trips.

backpackerItineraries.linkLabel: Positano on a backpacker budget: 1-3 day itineraries
intro: Pick a 1-, 2-, or 3-day plan that keeps costs down while still hitting the must-see views, beaches, and day trips.

toc.label: Day 2: Path of the Gods + beach

sections.title: Front-load the big climbs
body: Use arrival day for lower-town walks (Spiaggia Grande, Fornillo) and save the big stair days (Path of the Gods, Arienzo steps) for after a full night's sleep.
Group stops by elevation so you stay on one terrace level at a time; finish upper-town viewpoints before descending to the marina.

sections.title: One paid highlight per day
body: Budget for one paid experience each day (ferry to Capri, shared boat, garden entry), then fill the rest with free walks and beaches.
Stock up on snacks and water near Chiesa Nuova; waterfront cafes add the fastest markups.

sections.title: Viewpoints without ticket costs
body: Via Cristoforo Colombo gives the classic postcard angle at sunrise or golden hour, no entry fee.
For quieter photos, detour to the tiled courtyard by Chiesa Nuova or the small belvedere above Fornillo before 08:30.

sections.title: Budget swim breaks
body: Fornillo Beach has a free public section; walk the coastal path from Spiaggia Grande and rent only what you need.
For Arienzo's beach club vibe, take the stairs before 10:30 to claim public-space spots, then picnic with focaccia and fruit.

sections.title: Low-cost evenings
body: Sunset from the hostel terrace is free; mix a simple spritz with supermarket prosecco and share snacks.
Check the hostel noticeboard for socials; if you head out, arrive late when cover is lower and bring ID.

day1: Morning: Spiaggia Grande lookouts, then the coastal path to Fornillo for a swim.
Lunch: pizza al taglio or panini near Chiesa Nuova; eat on the terraces.
Sunset: Via Cristoforo Colombo or the hostel terrace.

day2: Morning: %LINK:pathOfTheGodsNocelle|Sentiero degli Dei / Path of the Gods% (bus to Nocelle, hike down to Positano).
Afternoon: %LINK:fornilloBeachGuide|cool down at Fornillo Beach% or a late lunch in town.

savings: Travel in shoulder months (April-May, late September) for lower prices and fewer crowds.
Use SITA buses for most hops; add a single ferry leg if you want the view.
Stay in dorms or share rooms near Chiesa Nuova to cut porter fees and stairs.
Refill water bottles at the hostel or public fountains before heading out.
If you booked direct, use the complimentary breakfast and evening drink to cover a meal.
Walk between viewpoints instead of hopping buses; the stairs are free and scenic.
backpackerItineraries.foodText: Think pizza al taglio, panini, and deli salads around Via dei Mulini and Chiesa Nuova. Stock up at mini-markets for picnic supplies and save sit-down meals for one treat.

faqs.q: What’s the best 1-day plan?
a: Start at Spiaggia Grande, walk the coastal path to Fornillo, then watch sunset from Via Cristoforo Colombo or the hostel terrace.

faqs.q: How can I keep transport costs low?
a: Use SITA buses for most trips and mix in one ferry leg for the view; buy tickets before boarding to avoid surprises.

faqs.q: What about a 2-day itinerary?
a: Day 1 covers Positano's essentials; Day 2 adds the Path of the Gods via Nocelle plus a beach cooldown.

faqs.q: Any 3-day add-ons?
a: Pick one: a Capri day trip or an Amalfi + Ravello combo; leave early and pack snacks to keep costs down.

seo.title: Backpacking Southern Italy: Route Including the Amalfi Coast
seo.description: A logical loop through highlights with budget transport notes.

backpackingSouthernItaly.linkLabel: Backpacking Southern Italy: Route incl. Amalfi
intro: Plan a loop through southern Italy that keeps Positano central without blowing the budget.

sections.title: Suggested loop
body: Start in Naples for flights and rail, spend 2–3 nights in Positano or nearby Praiano, continue to Salerno, then swing inland to Matera or Puglia before looping back.
Use regional trains and coach hops to cover longer legs cheaply; book 4–6 weeks ahead for €15–€25 seats.

sections.title: Arrivals & packing
body: Travel with a 40 L backpack so you can navigate staircases and bus luggage racks easily.
Pack quick-dry layers, a compact towel, and sandals for hostel showers; laundromats in Positano charge €12–€15 for wash-and-dry loads.

sections.title: Budget hacks
body: Pair grocery runs (fresh focaccia, fruit, mozzarella) with terrace picnics; budget €8 for lunch instead of €18 seated meals.
Split day trips with hostelmates: share taxi transfers to trailheads or rent scooters in Salerno/Praiano where rates drop to €35 per day.

tips: Activate a regional SIM or eSIM (TIM/Vodafone) so you can load bus schedules and hostel check-ins on the move.
Reserve hostels or guesthouses for the first and last nights of your loop, then stay flexible mid-trip for weather pivots.

faqs.q: Do I need to rent a car?
a: No. Trains, buses, and ferries cover the loop. Renting a scooter for short legs can be fun, but road traffic around Amalfi requires confidence.

faqs.q: How many days should I allow for Positano?
a: Give yourself at least three nights: one for Positano itself, one for a Path of the Gods or boat day, and a flex day for Amalfi/Ravello or weather backups.

seo.title: Best beaches in Positano
seo.description: Overview of Positano beaches: Spiaggia Grande, Fornillo, Arienzo, and how to reach them.

intro: To ensure that you have a great beach day, we have compiled a list of the main beaches available. The list is presented in table format, providing an overview of the features and amenities offered by each beach.

For more information about each beach, click on the name of the beach in the table below. This will take you to our guides, each of which include travel directions and descriptions of the various sections of the beach.

sections.title: Guides, including directions
body: Tap or click the beach names below to jump into our detailed guides. Each one covers transport directions, where the free and paid zones begin, and tips for navigating the different sections.

sections.title: Positano beaches
body: Fornillo, Spiaggia Grande, Arienzo, and Laurito are the main choices within walking or shuttle distance of the hostel. Use the cliffside walkway or local water taxis to move between them, and plan ahead if you want bus or boat rides back uphill after a long day.

sections.title: Praiano beaches
body: Praiano’s coves make easy day trips from Positano. Gavitella is the sunset favourite for aperitivo and dinner, while Marina di Praia is a working fishing village with beach clubs and a small public platform tucked between the boats.

sections.title: Furore beach
body: Fiordo di Furore is the dramatic fjord-style beach that you see on Instagram. It is free to access, but transport and the steep staircases make planning essential, especially if you want to leave before the small parking area fills up.

sections.title: Sorrento beaches
body: Regina Giovanna Bath is the standout option for a swim in Sorrento. It is a natural pool with free access, cool water, and cliffside views — perfect if you want to escape the crowds for an afternoon.

sections.title: Amalfi beaches
body: The town beach in Amalfi sits opposite the marina and is lined with lidos such as Stella Maris, Marina Grande Beach Club, Silver Moon, Bagni Mar di Cobalto, and Tonino ò Beach. Reserve ahead in peak months or arrive early to claim a public spot.

sections.title: Capri day trips
body: If you are hopping over to Capri, the main beach areas to note are Marina di Mulo, Bagni di Tiberio, and Marina Grande. Each offers paid loungers with clear water and quick ferry access back to the island’s transport links.

prosCons.title: Fornillo (Positano)
pros: Pupetto, Grassi, Ferdinando, and La Marinella beach clubs all start around €15 for a lounger set.
Two public sections, including a lesser-known ‘secret’ stretch beyond the main free zone.
cons: The walk back up to Hostel Brikette is steep; if you are tired, head to the main beach and take the local bus uphill.

prosCons.title: Spiaggia Grande (Positano)
pros: Classic Positano postcard views with the town as a backdrop.
Public area available if you arrive early enough.
cons: L’Incanto starts at about €25 per lounger, while La Scogliera ranges from roughly €100 to €400.
Most guests prefer the atmosphere and value at Fornillo.

prosCons.title: Arienzo (Positano)
pros: Packages with loungers, lunch, and drinks start near €60 and offer strong value for the location.
Enjoys long hours of sunshine and sweeping views down the coast.
cons: Access is challenging unless you book the beach club’s water taxi or commit to the long stair climb.

prosCons.title: Laurito (Positano)
pros: Da Adolfo includes loungers when you order from the restaurant, while Villa Tre Ville’s set starts around €30.
Long sun exposure and signature views; Da Adolfo is iconic and Villa Tre Ville feels exclusive.
cons: Reaching the cove is easiest via the beach club water taxis, and the free section is extremely small.

prosCons.title: Gavitella (Praiano)
pros: Perfect late in the day for sunset swims, aperitivo, and dinner on the terrace.
cons: Concrete bathing platforms dominate during daylight hours, so space can feel limited without a reservation.
No fully free section — expect to pay for a lounger if you stay long.

prosCons.title: Marina di Praia (Praiano)
pros: Fishing village ambience with seafood trattorie right on the water.
Small public access point lets you swim without booking a lido.
cons: The narrow cove loses sun earlier in the afternoon.
Beach clubs line most of the shoreline, so book ahead for loungers.

prosCons.title: Fiordo di Furore
pros: Free entry with dramatic cliffs and natural shade.
Popular for cliff jumping and photography; it’s the Instagram classic.
cons: Transport logistics and steep staircases make arrivals and departures tricky, especially when parking fills up.

prosCons.title: Regina Giovanna Bath (Sorrento)
pros: Relatively unknown natural pool with crystal-clear water.
Free to access and a refreshing break from Sorrento’s marinas.
cons: Rocky access requires sturdy footwear and care when entering the water.
No on-site facilities — bring water, snacks, and sun protection.

prosCons.title: Amalfi town beach
pros: Central location opposite the ferry pier with multiple lidos to choose from.
Options include Stella Maris, Marina Grande Beach Club, Silver Moon, Bagni Mar di Cobalto, and Tonino ò Beach.
cons: Premium pricing in peak season; advance reservations recommended.
Public space is limited and fills quickly each morning.

a: Every beach highlighted here includes some form of public access, but paid lidos provide loungers, umbrellas, and food service. Plan ahead if you want guaranteed shade or water taxi transfers.

beachHoppingAmalfi.linkLabel: Beach hopping on the Amalfi Coast
intro: Plan a beach-hopping day that balances ferry rides, cliffside views, and downtime on the sand.

sections.title: Morning: Positano to Fornillo
body: Start early on Spiaggia Grande for a quick dip, then walk the coastal path to Fornillo by 09:30 for calmer water.
Reserve sunbeds ahead if you want shade; otherwise pack a lightweight umbrella.

sections.title: Midday: Amalfi or Atrani
body: Take a late-morning ferry to Amalfi and lunch on the pier before swimming at the town beach or Atrani's pocket cove.
Store bags in Amalfi's deposit so you can explore hands-free.

sections.title: Group tours & shared boats
body: See our %LINK:boatTours|Boat tours in Positano guide% if you'd rather hop between beaches on a shared boat instead of ferries.
Operators depart from Positano's main pier; arrive 15 minutes early and confirm Laurito or Arienzo swim stops when booking.

sections.title: Evening: Sunset swim
body: Finish at Laurito or Arienzo for golden-hour views; both face west for warm light and fewer crowds after 17:00.
Take the last ferry or book a return taxi to avoid uphill hikes in the dark.

tips: Carry a quick-dry towel and change of clothes so you stay comfortable on ferries.
Pack snacks and at least 1 L / 34 oz of water—beach kiosks can run low on busy days.

faqs.q: Do I need to pre-book sunbeds?
a: Yes in July–August. Contact beach clubs via WhatsApp the day before to secure front rows.

faqs.q: Can I bring my own food?
a: Most free sections allow picnics. Beach clubs typically permit small snacks but prefer you purchase drinks from their bar.

seo.title: Boat tours in Positano

intro: Boat tours let you trace the Amalfi Coast cliffs without fighting road traffic; book ahead in peak months and keep a weather backup.

sections.title: Group tours & shared boats
body: 3-hour shared cruises leave Positano mid-morning and include swim stops; expect €85–€120 per person in July–August.
Bring swim shoes and a light layer—the breeze is cooler offshore than on the terraces.

sections.title: Private charters
body: Skippers quote €550–€850 for half-day gozzo charters (up to 6 people) plus fuel; confirm inclusions like prosecco or towels.
Negotiate start times around sunrise or late afternoon if you want gentler light and fewer wakes from ferries.

sections.title: Weather & backup plans
body: Operators cancel when winds exceed Force 4; keep a bus or beach plan ready so the day stays relaxed.
Seas can be choppy even in summer—pack motion-sickness bands if you are prone.

tips: Arrive 20 minutes before departure to settle the balance and slip on provided deck shoes.
Carry a dry bag for phones and a 1 L (34 oz) water bottle; shade is limited onboard.

faqs.q: Do I need to pre-book?
a: Yes in May–September—boats often sell out a few days ahead, especially sunset slots.

faqs.q: Are towels included?
a: Group tours usually provide one per person; private skippers vary, so pack a quick-dry towel to be safe.

seo.title: Hostel Brikette → Positano ferry dock (port)
seo.description: Step-by-step walking route to Positano’s port with map landmarks, ticket tips, and boarding guidance.

intro: Heading to Positano’s port for a ferry? This is the easiest walk we’ve found from Hostel Brikette to Spiaggia Grande — with a quick map and photo landmarks for points 1–5.
Allow 20–30 minutes on foot (more with luggage), and note that Google Maps sometimes suggests longer detours to the beach — follow the route below instead.
beforeList: Check ferry times and prices at the operator booths at the port (they list the next departure on the sign).
Leave a buffer if you have luggage — there are stairs on this route and the port gets busy at peak times.
Aim to arrive early so you can buy tickets, find the right pier, and be ready when boarding starts.

sections.title: Getting to the port
body: Begin at the hostel and head towards Spiaggia Grande (Positano’s main beach).
The port is located on the right-hand side of the beach.
Allow 20–30 minutes for the walk from the hostel to the port.
Google Maps may not always provide the most direct route to the beach — use the map and step-by-step directions below.

At point 2, go off the road and walk straight ahead, taking the stairs.
[[figure:point-2]]

Follow the stairs down until you reach the next level.
[[figure:point-3]]

Walk to the end of the port and wait for boarding.

faqs.q: How long does it take to walk from Hostel Brikette to the port?

faqs.q: Where do I buy ferry tickets in Positano?

intro: Practical etiquette for dining, visiting churches, and sharing narrow lanes around Positano and the Amalfi Coast.

sections.title: Dining
body: Book ahead at peak times, be patient between courses, ask for the bill when ready, and tip modestly for standout service.

sections.title: Churches & dress
body: Cover shoulders inside churches and avoid passing through shops in swimwear.

sections.title: Shared lanes
body: Keep right on narrow stair lanes, let others pass, and take turns quickly at popular photo spots.

faqs.q: Do I need to tip?
a: Tips are optional; leave €1–€2 for standout service or round up the bill. Coperto already covers bread and table settings.

faqs.q: What should I wear inside churches?
a: Cover shoulders and knees, remove hats, and keep voices low. Carry a light scarf to slip over sleeveless tops.

seo.title: Ferragosto in Positano (Assumption Day)
seo.description: What to expect on August 15: crowds, closures, fireworks, and transport tips.

intro: Ferragosto on 15 August brings packed beaches, fireworks, and altered schedules—plan ahead so the holiday feels festive, not frantic.

sections.title: What to expect on the day
body: Shops and small groceries close early; stock up on snacks and water the evening before.
Expect beach crowds by 09:00 and amplified music along Spiaggia Grande leading up to the midnight fireworks.

sections.title: Bookings and reservations
body: Reserve restaurants and boat tours at least a week ahead; many require prepayment or card guarantees for holiday service.
Confirm porter services 24 hours in advance if you arrive or depart on the 15th—teams run reduced schedules.

sections.title: Beach and swimming tips
body: Bring your own umbrella for the public section; lido sunbeds sell out and prices jump to peak rates.
Swim early or at sunset when lifeguards have clearer sightlines; midday crowds make currents harder to judge.

sections.title: Transport backups
body: SITA buses operate holiday timetables with fewer runs; check the posted schedule and queue early.
Ferries can sell out; secure round-trip tickets the day before and have a bus plan if seas turn rough.

tips: Pack earplugs if your room faces the beach—the fireworks finale and post-show music can run past 01:00.
Carry small cash for church donation boxes if you attend the Assumption Mass; card payments are rarely accepted.

faqs.q: Are supermarkets closed all day?
a: Many close entirely or open for a short morning window. Buy essentials by the evening of the 14th.

faqs.q: Can I watch the fireworks from the hostel terrace?
a: Yes—the terrace has a clear line of sight over the bay. Arrive early to claim space and bring a light layer for the sea breeze.

seo.title: Ferry cancellations and rough seas
seo.description: What to do when ferries are cancelled due to weather, alternatives, and how to check status.

intro: Rough seas can suspend ferries to and from Positano with little notice.
Keep a land-based backup ready and monitor live alerts so you still make your connection.

sections.title: Monitor live updates
body: Check operator sites and apps (Travelmar, NLG, Alilauro) plus the port display boards every 30 minutes on windy days.
Enable SMS/email alerts or follow local Telegram/social channels so cancellations reach you even if you step away from the pier.

sections.title: Switch to land routes
body: If sailings stop, pivot to buses and trains: SITA to Sorrento then Circumvesuviana for Naples/Pompeii, or bus via Amalfi and regional train from Salerno.
Allow at least 60 minutes of buffer for the last departures of the day and validate tickets before boarding.

sections.title: Refunds & vouchers
body: Keep receipts and screenshot the cancellation notice so the operator can process refunds, rebooking, or credits.
Let staff know whether you prefer the next available sailing or a season voucher before you leave the counter.

sections.title: Managing overnight delays
body: Tell your accommodation or tour host as soon as delays are announced; many will adjust check-in or departure if warned in advance.
Ask the port info point about shared taxis, substitute shuttles, or bag storage if you need to wait for the following morning.

tips: Check the marine forecast—winds above 20 knots or swell over 1.5 metres (about 5 ft) often trigger cancellations.
Travel insurance that covers weather delays helps recover extra hotel nights or replacement transfers.
Morning sailings are the most reliable; avoid relying on the final boat of the day when storms are forecast.

faqs.q: How do I know when sailings resume?
a: Refresh the operator website or social feeds and listen for loudspeaker announcements at the pier—decisions are usually posted within 30 minutes of the scheduled departure.
Ticket-desk staff can also confirm if the next boat is running before you leave the port.

faqs.q: What happens to my ticket?
a: Show your receipt or QR code to request a refund, voucher, or rebooking on the next sailing.
If you booked via an online agency, email them the cancellation screenshot within 24 hours to start the refund process.

faqs.q: Are any ferries guaranteed in rough weather?
a: No—when the Coast Guard closes the harbour all departures stop. Have a land route ready.
A few private charters may sail in moderate seas but they’re expensive and depend on captain discretion; weigh comfort and cost carefully.

seo.title: Ferry dock → Hostel Brikette, with luggage

ferryDockToBrikette.linkLabel: Ferry dock → Hostel Brikette, with luggage
intro: Arriving by ferry with luggage? Combine the Interno Positano bus with Positano's porters to reach Hostel Brikette without hauling bags up steep staircases.
beforeList: Check the latest Interno Positano timetable — here’s the [current timetable and ticket prices](https://forum.amalfi.com/t/mobility-amalfi-coast-bus-positano-nocelle-praiano/26).
Buy Interno Positano tickets at any tabacchi/newsagent before boarding.
Consider handing heavy luggage to the porters as they meet the ferry – tell them you’re staying at Hostel Brikette.

sections.title: Port to Piazza dei Mulini
body: Walk from the main beach up to Piazza dei Mulini following the signed promenade — use [these directions](https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Positano+Spiaggia/2+Viale+Pasitea+Positano,+Campania/@40.6289096,14.4857482,18z/data=!4m14!4m13!1m5!1m1!1s0x133b976916d1a44d:0xf1e08d61658b4291!2m2!1d14.4878892!2d40.6276549!1m5!1m1!1s0x133b976f39841bc9:0x5425cf574fd9d282!2m2!1d14.4857716!2d40.6301562!3e2).

If you are carrying bags, consider hiring one of Positano’s porter services at the dock so they transport everything uphill for you — our [porter service guide](guide:porterServices) covers pricing and how to book.

sections.title: Piazza dei Mulini to the Interno bus stop
body: When you arrive at Piazza dei Mulini, pick up an interno bus ticket from one of the corner stores or ‘tabacchi’. And then go to the bus stop which is at the edge of the Piazza - where the Piazza joins the road.

The Interno bus runs every ~30 minutes from morning until midnight and follows [this uphill route](https://www.google.com/maps/dir/2+Viale+Pasitea+Positano,+Campania/Viale+Pasitea,+323,+84017+Positano+SA/@40.6309188,14.4819138,16z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m14!4m13!1m5!1m1!1s0x133b976f39841bc9:0x5425cf574fd9d282!2m2!1d14.4857716!2d40.6301562!1m5!1m1!1s0x133b97667312711d:0xa2b15bca59b377fa!2m2!1d14.4824389!2d40.6293416!3e0) towards the hostel.

sections.title: Spotting the Interno Positano bus
body: Fleet vehicles differ, but the electronic sign on the front will always read “interno positano.”
Expect a compact city bus with standing room; board at the curb and validate or show your ticket to the driver.

a: Pick up tickets at any tabacchi/newsstand in town, including the kiosk beside the bus stop. Drivers do not sell tickets onboard.

faqs.q: How often does the Interno Positano bus run?
a: Services are scheduled roughly every 30 minutes from about 08:00 until midnight, with extra departures in peak season — always confirm the timetable before sailing.

faqs.q: How do the dock porters work?
a: Porters meet each ferry, load your bags, and deliver them uphill. Tell them you are staying at Hostel Brikette, pay the quoted fee, and keep valuables or medication with you.

seo.title: Ferry schedules for Positano

intro: Ferry schedules to/from Positano: where to check live departures, how seasonality works, and how to keep backups ready.

sections.title: When ferries run
body: Core season runs roughly April–October with peak frequencies mid-May through September; winter sailings are rare and weather dependent.
Shoulder months often see the first and last departures trimmed — confirm the timetable the evening before.

sections.title: Check live updates
body: Use operator sites and apps (Travelmar, NLG, Alilauro, Positano Jet) plus port display boards for delay and gate changes.
Screenshot timetables and enable email/SMS alerts so sudden weather advisories reach you even without Italian SIM data.

sections.title: Tickets & buffers
body: High-season crossings can sell out hours ahead — buy online or the day before and arrive 30 minutes prior with ID and luggage ready for tagging.
Keep a margin before the last connection of the day so you can pivot to a bus or taxi if the sea turns rough.

tips: Monitor marine forecasts (wind above 20 knots or swell over 1.5 metres often triggers cancellations).
If you need to switch ports, check local bus times in advance so the connection stays stress-free.

faqs.q: When are summer timetables published?
a: Most operators release peak-season schedules between February and March; autumn updates usually land in late August.

faqs.q: How do I confirm a same-day cancellation?
a: Refresh the operator website or social feeds and look for printed notices at the pier; staff announce changes over loudspeakers as well.
Have the SITA bus timetable or a taxi contact handy in case you need to reroute immediately.

faqs.q: Can I travel with large luggage?
a: Yes, but oversized bags may incur a small supplement; arrive early so crew can tag and stow them safely while you keep valuables with you.

seo.title: Fiordo di Furore Beach Guide
seo.description: How to reach Fiordo di Furore by bus from Positano, what to pack, and what to expect at the cliffside cove.

intro: Fiordo di Furore is the Amalfi Coast’s postcard gorge — a narrow inlet beneath an arched bridge with emerald water and sheer cliffs. It is a small, mostly wild cove with no beach clubs or restaurants, so come prepared for a swim, a few photos, and dramatic cliff jumping.
Use this guide to travel by bus, understand how limited the facilities are, and plan your exit so you are not stranded once the last SITA service fills up.

sections.title: Ride the SITA bus confidently
body: From Hostel Brikette walk down Via Pasitea to the Sponda stop and board a SITA bus towards Amalfi. Tell the driver you need "Fiordo di Furore" so they remember to pull over — the stop sits between Praiano and Furore and can be easy to miss on a busy day.
After a 25-minute ride hop off at the marked stop just before the bridge. Follow the stairs carved into the cliff for a couple of minutes until you reach the shingle beach tucked beneath the arch.

sections.title: Plan your return before you swim
body: There are no ticket offices or machines in the gorge. Buy a round-trip ticket in Positano (tabacchi near Chiesa Nuova or the Sponda newsstand) and validate it when you board.

Summer buses can arrive already full after leaving Amalfi. Aim for an earlier departure than you think you need, and let fellow travellers at the stop know you are waiting so the driver keeps an eye out. If two buses pass without stopping, consider splitting a taxi from the road above.

sections.title: Expect raw beauty, not services
body: Fiordo di Furore has no beach clubs, no bathrooms, and only the occasional mobile snack cart in peak season. Pack water, snacks, and something comfortable to sit on — the pebbles are coarse and space is limited.

Cliff jumping happens from the rocks beside the bridge, but always check the depth first and jump only where locals are already in the water. Respect the swimmers below and keep an eye on the tides; the cove gets shady by late afternoon.

essentials: SITA bus stop between Praiano and Furore — ask the driver to call out the fiord.
Steep stairway down to a tiny shingle beach beneath the bridge.
No services on site: bring water, snacks, sun protection, and cash for emergency taxis.
typicalCosts: Guide prices are between 5 and 10 euros.
tips: Review our %LINK:positanoBeaches|beaches overview% to pair Fiordo di Furore with another swim spot on the same day.
Arrive early if you want photos without crowds under the bridge.
Pack reef-safe sunscreen and water shoes — the rocks are slick when wet.
warnings: Buy round-trip bus tickets in Positano; there is nowhere to purchase or validate them at the fiord.
Buses sometimes skip the stop when full in peak months — allow extra time to get home.
Space on the beach is tight and shade arrives quickly in the afternoon.
