seo.title: Fiordo di Furore beach → Hostel Brikette by bus
seo.description: Follow these steps to reach the SITA stop above Fiordo di Furore, ride back towards Positano, and finish the short walk to Hostel Brikette.

fiordoDiFuroreBusReturn.linkLabel: Fiordo di Furore beach → Hostel Brikette by bus
intro: Fiordo di Furore sits below the Amalfi Coast highway with no ticket office or shops once you reach the water. Use this return guide to climb back to the road, board the SITA bus toward Positano, and finish the walk to Hostel Brikette without guesswork.
warnings: Buy SITA tickets in advance — there is nowhere near the beach to purchase them, and drivers can refuse boarding without a validated ticket.

sections.title: Climb back to the road
body: Follow the staircase from the pebble beach up to the Amalfi Coast road.
The SITA bus stop sits right where the staircase meets the roadside lay-by; wait here on the mountain side of the road.

sections.title: Ride the SITA bus toward Positano
body: Board the SITA bus heading in the Positano direction — services are request based, so the number of intermediate stops depends on other passengers.
Expect the journey to cover roughly 10.8 kilometres (6.7 miles) along the coast before you reach Positano.

sections.title: Hop off at Bar Internazionale / Chiesa Nuova
body: Press the stop button shortly after the bus leaves the tunnel above Positano and watch for the Bar Internazionale tabacchi.
Disembark at the Chiesa Nuova stop; this is the closest SITA stop to Hostel Brikette.

sections.title: Walk the final stretch to Hostel Brikette
body: Continue in the same direction as the bus for just over 100 metres (330 feet).
Turn right at the staircase beside the bar and climb to the hostel’s front door.

tips: Check the latest timetable through the hostel’s digital concierge so you know when the next SITA bus is due.
Use the %LINK:positanoBeaches|Positano beaches overview% to plan other coastal swims that pair well with a Fiordo di Furore outing.
If a bus is full or cancelled, be prepared to flag a licensed taxi from the lay-by as a backup.

faqs.q: Where should I wait for the bus?
a: Stand on the mountain side of the road at the top of the staircase — buses heading toward Positano stop beside the crash barrier.

faqs.q: What if I do not have a ticket?
a: Drivers expect validated SITA tickets before boarding. Buy a return ticket in Positano or ask reception about current stock before you leave the hostel.

seo.title: Local Legends & Folklore of the Amalfi Coast
seo.description: Popular tales from around the coast plus where to see their traces.

folkloreAmalfi.linkLabel: Local Legends & Folklore of the Amalfi Coast
intro: Dive into Amalfi Coast legends and lore that shape festivals, statues, and local sayings.

sections.title: Saint Andrew
body: Amalfi Cathedral houses relics of Saint Andrew; locals credit him with calming storms and safeguarding fishermen.
Every 27 June and 30 November processions carry the saint's statue through town with fireworks and brass bands.

sections.title: Sirens of Li Galli
body: Myth says Li Galli islands lured sailors with song; today, boat tours share the legend as you pass the private islets.
Listen for references to Parthenope and the sirens when visiting Naples—they link the regions' myths.

sections.title: Living traditions
body: Praiano's Luminaria and Positano's fishing blessings blend faith and folklore with candlelit rituals.
Handmade ceramic tiles often depict saints, lemons, or coastal legends—spot them on doorways and church steps.

tips: Check municipal event calendars for feast days so you can join respectful celebrations.
Carry a lightweight shawl; many events lead into church services where modest dress is appreciated.

faqs.q: Can anyone join the processions?
a: Yes—stand along the route, clap respectfully, and allow locals carrying statues to pass first.

faqs.q: Where do I hear traditional music?
a: Look for folk concerts in Atrani and Ravello during summer festivals; tourist offices post weekly schedules.

seo.title: A Foodie’s Guide to Naples & the Amalfi Coast
seo.description: What to eat and where; classic dishes and local specialties.

foodieGuideNaplesAmalfi.linkLabel: A Foodie’s Guide to Naples & the Amalfi Coast
intro: Navigate the best bites between Naples and the Amalfi Coast with must-try dishes, markets, and local drinks.

sections.title: Naples essentials
body: Try classic pizza Margherita, fried pizza, and sfogliatella within a single day—pace yourself with espresso breaks.
Visit Pignasecca market for seafood, cheeses, and fresh produce to pack for the coast.

sections.title: Amalfi Coast specialties
body: Order scialatielli ai frutti di mare, delizia al limone, and locally made limoncello for a well-rounded tasting.
Seek out caseificio (dairy shops) for mozzarella, smoked provola, and caciocavallo you can enjoy on the hostel terrace.

sections.title: Street food & markets
body: Pick up cuoppo fritto cones, fried anchovies, or arancini for €4–€6 to keep hunger at bay between ferry hops.
Sunday farmers' markets in Positano and Praiano sell seasonal fruit and pastries—bring reusable bags.

tips: Book cooking classes early if you want hands-on pasta and dessert sessions—spots fill quickly in summer.
Note dietary needs when booking; many hosts can adjust menus with advance notice.

faqs.q: Can I do a food tour from Positano?
a: Yes. Join guided tastings in Naples or Sorrento; most start mid-morning so you can travel by early train or ferry.

faqs.q: Do restaurants cater to vegetarians?
a: Absolutely. Look for eggplant parmigiana, gnocchi alla sorrentina, salads, and vegetable antipasti across the region.

seo.title: Fornillo Beach guide
seo.description: Layout map, free sections, and beach club tips for Pupetto, Da Ferdinando, Grassi, and La Marinella — plus shortcuts to and from the hostel.

fornilloBeachGuide.linkLabel: Fornillo Beach guide: clubs & free spots
intro: Fornillo beach is a relaxed cove a short walk from the hostel. The beach clubs keep prices gentler than Spiaggia Grande, the public zones are generous, and the atmosphere stays low-key even in peak weeks.
Use the coastal walkway to move between beach sections, grab food from the bars, and loop back to Spiaggia Grande if you want the interno bus uphill.

sections.title: Layout and beach operators
body: Two main paths feed Fornillo. The shortcut from %LINK:hostelBriketteToFornilloBeach|Hostel Brikette% arrives at the left-hand side of the beach (when facing the sea); the waterfront promenade from Spiaggia Grande reaches the right-hand side.

Beach clubs run in sequence from the hostel access point toward the main beach path: Pupetto, Da Ferdinando, Fratelli Grassi, and La Marinella. Two public zones bookend the lidos — a wide free stretch beside Pupetto and a smaller cove beyond La Marinella.

sections.title: Main free section
body: The largest free section sits directly in front of the shortcut from the hostel. Arrive before 10:30 to claim a spot near the waterline; the pebbles warm quickly so pack a mat or thick towel.

Pupetto and Da Ferdinando both sell takeaway drinks and panini — perfect if you want food without renting a lounger. Keep an eye on the tide in shoulder months; autumn storms can shrink the shoreline for a day or two.

sections.title: Pupetto Beach Club
body: Pupetto anchors the left side of Fornillo with rows of orange loungers, showers, and a full-service restaurant. Reserve by WhatsApp or phone in summer if you want front-row seats; walk-ins are normally fine before 09:30.
Guests using the free area can still order takeaway from the bar, and Pupetto’s bathrooms are open to paying customers — handy if you decide to upgrade partway through the day.

sections.title: Da Ferdinando
body: Da Ferdinando keeps a chilled beach-bar vibe with blue loungers, paddleboard rentals, and a popular lunch menu (think grilled catch of the day, salads, and pasta). Expect prices a little higher than Pupetto but still reasonable for Positano.
Water taxis to Laurito and Arienzo swing by Da Ferdinando’s jetty — useful if you plan to beach-hop after a morning swim.

sections.title: Fratelli Grassi Beach Bar
body: Grassi is compact with neat rows of red loungers and a shaded bar for cocktails and granita. The team offers dry bags for valuables if you rent kayaks to explore the nearby caves.
Because space is limited, advance bookings help on weekends. Walk-ins are usually possible midweek after 11:00 once early reservations settle.

sections.title: La Marinella
body: La Marinella sits closest to the Spiaggia Grande walkway and catches midday sun. Expect attentive service, lunch platters, and the option to book upper-deck loungers with extra shade.
In shoulder season La Marinella sometimes relocates a few chairs into the neighbouring cove. Staff should leave space for the public area, but be prepared for a tighter footprint when seas are rough.

sections.title: ‘Secret’ free section
body: Beyond La Marinella, a small cove offers a quieter public area with a pebble shelf and calm water. Bring reef-friendly sunscreen and water shoes — the entry is rocky and sea urchins can cluster near the edges.

La Marinella occasionally sets spare loungers here on stormy days. The zone remains officially free, so feel comfortable using the space if you arrive first; just leave room for returning chairs or kayaks.

essentials: Suncream
Sunglasses
Towel
typicalCosts: Between 0 and 50 euros, depending on whether you rent a lounger, eat, or drink.
tips: Follow the %LINK:hostelBriketteToFornilloBeach|shortcut route% down for the fastest descent (15–20 minutes).
When you are ready to leave, take the %LINK:fornilloBeachToBrikette|return route% along the promenade and ride the interno bus back up to Chiesa Nuova.
Compare prices and alternative coves in our %LINK:positanoBeaches|Positano beaches overview% before you book loungers.
warnings: Fornillo is pebbled — pack water shoes or sandals for the shoreline.
Shade is limited after late morning, so plan to rent a parasol or bring a hat and sunscreen.
Card machines occasionally go offline; carry some cash for bar tabs and lounger balances.

faqs.q: Do I need to reserve a lounger?
a: Reservations help on summer weekends. Pupetto and La Marinella answer by phone or WhatsApp; Da Ferdinando and Grassi also monitor Instagram DMs. Early arrivals before 09:30 can usually grab walk-in spots.

faqs.q: Can I bring my own food?
a: Picnics are welcome in the free sections. If you rent loungers, stick to small snacks and water bottles unless the club confirms otherwise. Every operator has a bar or restaurant for larger meals.

faqs.q: Where can I shower or use the bathroom?
a: Facilities belong to each beach club. Ask at the bar before using them if you are in the public zone — many allow quick visits for a small fee or when you buy food or drinks.

seo.title: Fornillo Beach → Hostel Brikette return route
seo.description: Follow the waterfront to Spiaggia Grande, browse the shops, and ride the interno bus back up to the hostel.

fornilloBeachToBrikette.linkLabel: Fornillo Beach → Hostel Brikette return route
intro: Heading back to Hostel Brikette from Fornillo Beach is easiest if you follow the waterfront to Spiaggia Grande and ride the interno bus from the town centre. This route swaps most of the uphill stairs for level promenades and a short climb beside the hostel.

sections.title: Plan your return
body: Allow extra time for photo stops or browsing the shops around Spiaggia Grande before you board the bus.
This return path is longer than climbing the shortcut staircase, but it stays cooler in the afternoon and gives you a gentler finish after a beach day.

sections.title: Route from Fornillo Beach to Hostel Brikette
body: 1. Walk to the far left side of Fornillo Beach (left when you face the sea).
2. Follow the coastal path toward Spiaggia Grande until you reach the main beach and port area.
3. Pass through the harbour gate, leave the jetty, and continue straight along the waterfront promenade.
4. Take the pathway directly ahead off the beachfront and continue inland.
5. Turn right at the first alley between the shops.
6. Climb the staircase that leads up to Chiesa di Santa Maria Assunta.
7. At the top of the lane, turn left and follow it uphill.
8. When the lane meets the one-way road at the junction, you have reached the interno bus stop for Chiesa Nuova. Ride it up one stop for Hostel Brikette.

sections.title: Catch the interno bus
body: From the Chiesa Nuova stop, the orange interno Positano bus drops you a short walk from Hostel Brikette—perfect if you want to avoid the full stair climb back.
Tickets are sold at tabacchi/newsagent kiosks throughout town, so buy them before you head down or check with reception for availability.

tips: Buy interno bus tickets at any tabacchi/newsagent before you go to the beach.
Save the stair-heavy shortcut for mornings; this scenic return is calmer after a long swim.
Link it with our %LINK:fornilloBeachGuide|Fornillo beach guide% for beach club details and quiet spots.
Review the %LINK:positanoBeaches|Positano beaches overview% to plan where else to swim during your stay.

faqs.q: How long does the return take?
a: Walking back via Spiaggia Grande adds around 10 extra minutes compared with the direct staircase, but you avoid most of the steep climb before boarding the bus.

faqs.q: Where do I catch the bus?
a: Ride the orange interno Positano bus from the Chiesa Nuova stop at the top of the lane. It drops you near the hostel, and tickets come from tabacchi/newsagent kiosks.

sections.title: Viewpoints worth the climb
body: Start at the terrace outside Chiesa Nuova for sunrise colours washing over the bay; bring a 500 ml (17 oz) bottle because there are no taps nearby.
Walk Via Cristoforo Colombo and the Viale Pasitea balconies around golden hour for postcard angles without booking a table.

sections.title: Free beach time
body: Spiaggia Grande reserves a public strip on the right-hand side—pack a light towel and sit close to the waterline to avoid lido rows.
Follow the coastal path to Fornillo Beach for a quieter cove; the walk takes about 12 minutes with modest stairs and the public section stays free.

sections.title: DIY walking routes
body: Explore the narrow lanes in the Liparlati district, ducking into tiny courtyards and ceramic-lined staircases between Via dei Mulini and Via Pasitea.
Take the free shuttle to Montepertuso’s stop and descend the ancient stone steps back to Positano in about 25–35 minutes, pausing at the natural arch viewpoint.

sections.title: Culture without a ticket
body: Step inside Santa Maria Assunta to view the Byzantine icon and majolica dome; shoulders covered is enough dress code.
Check the commune noticeboard near Piazza dei Mulini for evening concerts or films hosted on the beach during summer weeks.

tips: Carry a reusable bottle and refill at the public fountain near Chiesa Nuova before you head to viewpoints.
Pack reef-safe sunscreen and a sarong; they double as a beach mat and light cover in churches.

faqs.q: Are there free showers on the beaches?
a: Yes—Spiaggia Grande has cold-water showers near the public section. Bring flip-flops because the floor gets hot by midday.

faqs.q: Do I need tickets for the Path of the Gods?
a: The trail itself is free year-round. Budget for the €2.40 SITA bus ride up to Nocelle and back if you do not want to hike both ways.

seo.title: Gavitella Beach Guide
seo.description: Plan a sunset-friendly day at Praiano's La Gavitella and One Fire beach clubs with transport, reservations, and return tips.

intro: Praiano's Gavitella cove faces west, giving you long afternoon sun and golden-hour views back to Positano and Capri. Two lidos — La Gavitella and One Fire — share the small shoreline beside a compact public section carved into the rock.
Expect a curated, reservation-driven experience: steep stairs limit crowds, the clubs coordinate boat shuttles, and evenings revolve around seafood dinners or DJ-led sunset parties.

sections.title: Layout and vibe
body: The beach sits below Praiano's Piazza San Gennaro. Roughly 400 steps weave past villas and lemon terraces to a stone platform, a pebble shelf, and a slim free zone between the two lidos.

La Gavitella occupies the left-hand side (facing the sea) with restaurant tables, sun decks, and moorings for dinner guests. One Fire lines the right-hand pier with bright loungers, a DJ podium, and a dock for their party boats.

sections.title: How to reach Gavitella
body: From Hostel Brikette or central Positano, ride the SITA bus toward Amalfi and hop off at Praiano's Piazza San Gennaro stop; give yourself 10–15 minutes to descend the stairway for your booking.

Praiano's interno shuttle loops between the upper road and Marina di Praia — use it for the return so you are not climbing hundreds of steps after sunset. Both clubs can also arrange boat shuttles from Positano or Marina di Praia when seas are calm.

sections.title: La Gavitella Beach Club
body: La Gavitella is all about slow lunches, aperitivi, and a sunset boat spin around the Li Galli islets. The kitchen focuses on seasonal seafood — crudo platters, paccheri with local fish, and a lemon-forward dessert list.
Mention transfer needs when you reserve: staff coordinate tender boats for dinner guests and can store bags while you swim before the aperitif cruise.

sections.title: One Fire Beach Club
body: One Fire is the Amalfi Coast's party beach, famous for its afternoon watermelon ritual, DJ sets, and crowd choreography timed perfectly with the sunset.
Book loungers or cabanas via WhatsApp — deposits are common in July and August. When seas behave, their boats shuttle groups from Positano and back after the music winds down.

sections.title: Facilities & planning
body: Both clubs include showers, changing cabins, and paid lockers; towels usually come with the lounger fee. Pack reef-safe sunscreen and water shoes for the stone platform and pebble entry.
A tiny public strip separates the lidos. Space is scarce, so arrive before 10:00 with your own mat, and expect staff to reclaim chairs if swells push them inland.

The free section can vanish during rough seas — keep a backup plan for windy days.
Boat shuttles pause when the sea turns, so confirm your return ride before sunset events begin.

faqs.q: How do I reach Gavitella from Hostel Brikette?
a: Walk to the Chiesa Nuova stop and board the SITA bus toward Amalfi. Get off at Praiano's Piazza San Gennaro, then follow the signed stairway for roughly 400 steps to the beach. In calm weather you can also pre-book boat shuttles from Positano's main pier.

faqs.q: Do I need to reserve in advance?
a: Yes. Contact La Gavitella or One Fire via WhatsApp or their online forms, share your arrival time, and ask about deposits. Weekends and sunset slots sell out quickly from June through September.

faqs.q: Is there a free area if I don't rent loungers?
a: A narrow public strip sits between the two clubs. Bring a mat or water shoes, arrive early, and respect any ropes or walkways staff set for boat access.

faqs.q: Can I stay for dinner or late events?
a: La Gavitella serves dinner on the terrace and often pairs it with a short boat cruise. One Fire runs sunset parties that finish around the last interno bus. Confirm return transport with staff so you are not climbing the stairs at night.

seo.title: Groceries and pharmacies in Positano
seo.description: Where to buy essentials in Positano: small supermarkets, late openings, and pharmacy info.

intro: You will not find large supermarkets in Positano, so plan for compact shops, a weekly market, and a couple of reliable pharmacies for essentials.

sections.title: Mini-markets & delis
body: Local delis on Via Pasitea and Via dei Mulini stock fresh bread, cheeses, and ready-made salads; expect limited shelf space but daily deliveries.
Opening hours follow the siesta rhythm—shop before 13:00 or after 16:30 to avoid shutters.

sections.title: Produce & markets
body: Fruit and vegetable stands set up near the Sponda bend and Chiesa Nuova stop each morning; carry small coins for quick purchases.
On Wednesdays, Montepertuso hosts a small market (bus 13) with seasonal vegetables, dairy, and cured meats.

sections.title: Pharmacies & health items
body: Farmacia Positano (Via Pasitea) keeps core medicines, sun care, and motion-sickness tablets; bring prescriptions for anything specialised.
After-hours service rotates—check the notice on the pharmacy door for the on-call number if you need medication late.

sections.title: Late-night essentials
body: A few alimentari stay open until 22:00 in high season; otherwise grab snacks at the 24-hour vending machines near the bus stops.
For urgent needs, Sorrento (45–60 minutes by bus) has larger supermarkets and a hospital emergency room.

tips: Bring a lightweight tote or backpack so you can carry groceries up stairs without overloading one hand.
Keep reusable water bottles: most shops sell 1.5 L refills cheaply, and hostel terraces have filtered taps.

faqs.q: Can I buy gluten-free items locally?
a: Yes—look for “senza glutine” shelves in the mini-markets or ask the pharmacist; stock is limited so buy when you see it.

faqs.q: Are pharmacies open on Sundays?
a: At least one stays open with reduced hours; check the posted rota and call ahead for prescription needs.

seo.title: The History of Positano (concise)
seo.description: A short history of Positano: traders, cliffs, and tourism.

intro: Understand Positano's past—from maritime roots to Hollywood discovery—so your walks have historical context.

sections.title: Origins & trade
body: Positano began as a Roman seaside villa hub; later, medieval traders exported wool and imported spices via Amalfi's fleet.
The watchtowers along the coast warned of Saracen raids—many survive as viewpoints today.

sections.title: 20th-century transformation
body: After World War II, artists and writers such as Steinbeck publicised Positano's charm, shifting the economy toward tourism.
Improved roads in the 1950s connected Positano to the rest of Italy, ushering in boutique hotels and visitors.

sections.title: Modern day
body: Tourism now anchors the town, with efforts to balance preservation and visitor numbers through ferry quotas and pedestrian zones.
Local artisans still craft sandals and ceramics, keeping heritage trades alive alongside hospitality.

tips: Visit the Roman Villa museum under Santa Maria Assunta to see mosaics unearthed in 1987.
Look for information plaques along Via dei Mulini that highlight key historic buildings.

faqs.q: Where can I learn more on site?
a: The MAR Positano museum combines archaeology and multimedia displays, ideal for rainy days.

faqs.q: Why are there so many stairs?
a: The town was built vertically to adapt to cliffs; staircases replaced streets for quick movement between terraces.

seo.title: Hitchhiking the Amalfi Coast (Is it Possible?)
seo.description: Why buses are the safer bet on narrow coastal roads.

intro: Hitchhiking on the Amalfi Coast sounds adventurous, but the SS163 is narrow with blind bends and almost no safe pull‑offs.
Lean on the public transport network instead: carry validated tickets, plan backup routes, and keep emergency cash for taxis or porters if services stop.

sections.title: Safety reality
body: Coaches, buses, and scooters already share a single lane carved into the cliff. Drivers cannot see you in time and police will often move people along for their own safety.
Night visibility is poor and shoulders are tiny — waiting on the carriageway risks injury and fines.

sections.title: Better alternatives
body: SITA buses, local shuttles, and community vans run all day; buy tickets ahead at tabacchi and validate on board.
Seasonal ferries give scenic hops between towns; when seas cancel them, revert to bus + porter service or shared taxis.
Short walking paths (Nocelle ↔ Positano, Praiano ↔ coastal hamlets) provide scenic backups in daylight.

sections.title: If you’re stranded
body: Call a licensed taxi (numbers are posted at major stops) or ask your accommodation/hostel bar to book one; late‑night rates are higher, so split fares with other travellers when possible.
Message your host if you’re delayed. The hostel team can suggest the safest pickup point or overnight alternatives in Sorrento/Amalfi.

tips: Screenshot bus and ferry schedules from UnicoCampania or Travelmar each morning so you know the last guaranteed departure.
Carry a small torch or reflective band if you expect to walk after sunset — roadside lighting is limited.
warnings: Never wait inside tunnels or on blind bends — local police can fine you and drivers have no space to avoid pedestrians.

faqs.q: Is hitchhiking legal on the Amalfi Coast?
a: There’s no explicit regional ban, but law enforcement discourages it and may ask you to move for safety. If officers intervene, follow their instructions and relocate to a bus stop.

faqs.q: What if the last bus has already left?
a: Use posted taxi numbers, rideshare apps that operate locally, or ask nearby hotels/bars to call a driver. As a final fallback, ride to Amalfi or Sorrento (larger towns) where night buses and trains are more frequent.

faqs.q: What should I do if the bus is full when it arrives?

2. Enter the main beach through the port and exit the jetty, then walk straight ahead.
3. Take the walkway off the beachfront straight ahead, then take the first right between the shops.
4. Climb the steps to the Church of Santa Maria Assunta, head left up the lane, and reach the one-way road at the top.

body: Keep tripods compact and step aside once you’ve taken a frame so staircases stay passable.

tips: Pack swimwear and a light towel even if you only plan to explore—thermal pools are irresistible after sightseeing.
Stay overnight on Ischia for relaxed evenings and to catch sunrise at the castle before day-trippers arrive.

faqs.q: Can I visit both islands in one day?

faqs.q: Do I need reservations for thermal parks?

Day 2: Morning ferry to Amalfi for Duomo and lemon granita, afternoon bus up to Ravello, then return to Positano for dinner.

Use day 4 for the Path of the Gods or a boat tour; keep a rainy-day swap like Pompeii ready.

sections.title: 5–6 day slow roll

Plan a beach-hop day between Arienzo, Laurito, and Marina di Praia using coastal ferries or water taxis.

tips: Pre-book long legs (Capri ferries, Pompeii train) but keep at least one buffer day for weather disruptions.
Group activities by geography so you only climb big stair sets once per day.

faqs.q: How many nights should I stay in Positano?

seo.title: Laurito Beach Guide
seo.description: Choose between Da Adolfo and Tre Ville, learn how the shuttle boats work, and plan a stress-free beach day in Laurito.

intro: Laurito is a pocket-sized cove tucked between Positano and Praiano. Two beach clubs — Da Adolfo and Villa Tre Ville — dominate the shoreline, leaving just a sliver of public sand. The reward is west-facing sunshine, iconic lunch spots, and a quieter atmosphere than Spiaggia Grande.
Use this guide to decide which club suits your style, understand how the water taxis operate, and map out the bus-and-stairs route back to Hostel Brikette.

sections.title: Why Laurito is worth the effort
body: Laurito sits just outside Positano’s centre, so crowds thin out compared with Spiaggia Grande. Sun hits the deck until early evening, the water stays calm for swimming, and the cliff backdrop makes for classic Amalfi Coast photos.
You will need either a confirmed reservation or patience for the tiny free strip, but once you are settled it is one of the most relaxed spots within a short ride of Hostel Brikette.

sections.title: Layout and who runs what
body: The cove splits into three zones. A narrow public area sits on the far right for those who bring their own towels. Villa Tre Ville’s club occupies the central decks with terracotta loungers, while Da Adolfo operates the left-hand side with wooden beds and the restaurant terrace.
All guests arrive by boat or via the steep stairway from the SITA bus stop. Expect to queue at peak times because both clubs control access to most of the shoreline.

sections.title: Villa Tre Ville beach club
body: Villa Tre Ville hosts a boutique club with limited loungers, attentive service, and pricing to match. Expect premium day beds, à la carte dining, and prosecco served to your chair.
Reservations run through the hotel concierge. Seats can exceed €200 for two in high season, but include towels, showers, and return boat service to Spiaggia Grande.
Late afternoon is particularly scenic; staff often arrange sunset spritz tastings before the final shuttle back to Positano.

sections.title: Da Adolfo beach club
body: Da Adolfo is famous for its grilled mozzarella on lemon leaves and relaxed, bohemian vibe. Booking is notoriously difficult — they reply slowly, and day-of slots go to returning guests first.

If you cannot secure a reservation, arrive early at Spiaggia Grande and ask to join the Da Adolfo water taxi as a standby guest. Once at the dock, staff will add you to their waitlist for any no-shows.
Lounger packages hover around €50–€70 for two people including the shuttle. Lunch mains run €18–€26 and the kitchen stays open through late afternoon.

sections.title: Logistics, tickets, and getting back
body: Water taxis for both clubs depart from the small pier on Spiaggia Grande. Boats typically run every 30 minutes from 09:30 until early afternoon, then resume returns around 15:00. Keep an eye on the chalkboard at the dock for changes when seas are rough.

Prefer public transport? Follow our %LINK:lauritoBeachBusDown|bus guide% for the outbound journey and %LINK:lauritoBeachBusBack|return guide% for the climb back. Buy your bus tickets before leaving town — there is nowhere to purchase them at Laurito.

On the way home, the coastal bus towards Sorrento or Positano stops beside the staircase entrance. Services thin out after 19:00, so confirm the last departure or budget for a taxi arranged via the hostel.

faqs.q: Do I need a reservation?

seo.description: What to try in Positano: limoncello, seafood staples, lemon desserts, and ordering etiquette.

intro: Lemons and limoncello define Amalfi flavours — from tasting flights to sweet finales.
Here’s where to sip, what to buy, and how to cook with them back home.

sections.title: Tasting
body: Visit small botteghe for artisan limoncello and ask for a sample to compare styles.
Pair tastings with lemon gelato, sorbet, or pastries to gauge sweetness and balance.

sections.title: Buying & shipping
body: Check airline liquid limits; pack bottles securely in checked luggage.
Look for IGP Costa d’Amalfi labels and recyclable packaging from local producers.

sections.title: Cooking with lemons
body: Use zest and juice in salads, seafood pasta, and desserts for brightness.
Store lemons in a cool, dark spot and repurpose peels for syrups or marinades.

tips: Support small producers — flavours are often more intense than tourist-trap brands.
Skip overpriced souvenir shops near the main beach; head a street or two back for better value.

faqs.q: Can I carry limoncello in hand luggage?
a: Not over 100 ml — pack standard bottles in checked bags with padding.

faqs.q: Are there alcohol-free alternatives?
a: Try fresh lemonade, granita, or lemon syrups if you prefer to skip alcohol.

seo.title: Inside a Limoncello Factory
seo.description: How limoncello is made and what to look for in a quality bottle.

limoncelloFactory.fallbackParagraph: What goes into real limoncello: lemons, alcohol, sugar, and time. Tours show the process and end with tastings — don’t drive afterwards.
intro: Touring a limoncello laboratory shows how sfusato Amalfitano lemons become the coast’s signature digestivo.
Learn the stages, taste small-batch bottles, and pick up tips on storing and transporting your favourite blend home.

sections.title: Sfusato Amalfitano lemons
body: Producers use thick-skinned sfusato Amalfitano lemons grown on terraced pergolas; their essential oils sit in the zest, not the juice.
Good tours start with a look at how the fruit is peeled by hand and why organic farming matters for a clean, aromatic infusion.

sections.title: From zest to infusion
body: Fresh zest steeps in neutral grain alcohol for a week or more until the liquid turns golden and fragrant.
After the infusion, the liquid is filtered and blended with simple syrup; batches rest to marry flavours before bottling.

sections.title: What tastings include
body: Guides usually walk you through the workspace, then pour small tastings of limoncello, crema di limone, or seasonal liqueurs.
Sip slowly, note texture and aroma, and skip driving afterwards—the samples are full strength even if they feel smooth.

sections.title: Buying and storing a bottle
body: Choose opaque glass or UV-protected bottles, and check labels for the producer’s address and production date.
Keep your bottle chilled once you open it at home; if you plan to travel with it, cushion it in clothing or ask the shop for protective packaging.

faqs.q: Can under-18 visitors join a tour?
a: Yes, minors can observe the process but legally cannot taste; some producers offer lemonades or granita as an alternative.

faqs.q: How can I bring limoncello home safely?
a: Pack bottles in checked luggage (carry-on limits prohibit liquids over 100 ml), cushion them well, and declare quantities if your country has strict alcohol import limits.

faqs.q: How long does limoncello keep?
a: Unopened bottles stay fresh for up to a year; once opened, store them in the fridge or freezer and enjoy within a few months for peak aroma.

a: Yes, viewing is free. Support local stalls by buying snacks or donating at the church to help fund candles for future years.

faqs.q: What if it rains?

seo.title: Marina di Praia Beach Guide
seo.description: Bus directions, beach layout, and dinner tips for Praiano’s hidden cove.

intro: Marina di Praia is Praiano’s tucked-away pebble cove — a short bus ride from Hostel Brikette but far quieter than Positano’s headline beaches. Fishing boats, a historic watchtower, and stone walkways wrap the bay so you still have services without the crowds.
Use this guide to ride the bus there and back confidently, understand how the lido works, and plan a relaxed dinner before heading home.

sections.title: Why add Marina di Praia to your beach list
body: Unlike Spiaggia Grande or Fornillo, Marina di Praia sits in a narrow gorge just outside Praiano. The cliffs shelter the water from swells, fishing boats bob in the harbour, and the vibe stays low key even in August.
It is an easy add-on to a Praiano day trip or a change of scenery mid-week. The smaller footprint means fewer loungers overall, but you trade that for calmer crowds and photogenic scenery for sunset.

sections.title: Getting there and back by bus
body: From Hostel Brikette walk down Via Pasitea to the Sponda bus stop and catch the SITA bus heading towards Amalfi. Ask the driver for "Marina di Praia" so they know to stop — it is roughly 20 minutes from Positano depending on traffic.

Hop off at the signed stop (between Praiano and Furore) and follow the stone path downhill for two minutes to the waterfront. The walk is paved the entire way. For the return journey, wait at the same stop on the opposite side; buses towards Positano usually run every 30–40 minutes in season but thin out after 20:30.

Buy and validate your SITA tickets before boarding — the tobacconist near the Chiesa Nuova stop and the newsstand in Positano both stock them. Review the %LINK:sitaTickets|SITA bus guide% if you need a refresher on ticket types and late-night options.

sections.title: Beach layout and operators
body: A small public strip sits at the centre of the cove — arrive before 10:30 if you want a free spot near the water. The main operator is Marina di Praia Beach Club with rows of loungers, parasols, showers, and kayak rentals; expect packages from €25–€35 for a chair and umbrella in high season.

Along the walkway you will also find Da Armandino and Il Pirata restaurants plus small kiosks for cold drinks. Card machines can be temperamental, so carry enough cash for lounger balances or a seafood lunch.
Shade disappears early because the cliffs block the sun, so plan a morning swim, then transition to bar seating or a late lunch as the bay cools down.

sections.title: Stay for dinner without stress
body: The cove transforms after sunset: strings of lights reflect on the water and restaurants shift to full dinner service. Reserve ahead if you have your heart set on Da Armandino or Il Pirata — both specialise in fresh catch and house-made pasta.

Aim for the 21:00 SITA bus back towards Positano (times vary by season) or split a taxi with friends if you linger for dessert. The ride back drops you at Sponda so you only have a short uphill walk to the hostel.

essentials: 20-minute SITA bus ride from Positano; ask for the Marina di Praia stop and walk two minutes downhill.
Narrow pebble beach with one main lido plus a small free section in the middle.
Restaurants and snack kiosks line the walkway — ideal for a sunset dinner before heading home.
typicalCosts: Lounger + umbrella at Marina di Praia Beach Club: €25–€35 for the day (two-person sets available).
Kayak hire: around €20 per hour for two people.
Dinner mains at Da Armandino or Il Pirata: €16–€28 depending on catch and pasta specials.
tips: Validate your bus ticket as soon as you board and keep a spare for the ride home in case the kiosk is closed in the evening.
Pack water shoes — the pebbles can be slick and the shoreline drops off quickly.
Compare other coastal options in our %LINK:positanoBeaches|beaches overview% if you want to pair Marina di Praia with a Positano day.
warnings: Space is limited; the free area fills first and lido loungers sell out on weekends.
The cliffs block direct sun by mid-afternoon — great for cooling down but it can feel chilly on windy days.
Mobile reception dips inside the gorge; download bus timetables or dinner booking confirmations beforehand.

faqs.q: Where exactly do I catch the bus from Positano?
a: Use the Sponda stop on Via Pasitea for buses heading towards Amalfi. It is a 10-minute walk downhill from the hostel; arrive 10 minutes early in high season so you can board before the bus fills up.

faqs.q: Is there a free area or do I have to rent loungers?
a: A modest public strip sits in the centre of the cove. Bring a mat or thick towel — the pebbles are coarse — and be ready to slide closer to the rocks as the tide shifts. Loungers at the Marina di Praia Beach Club include showers and bathrooms if you prefer a set-up.

faqs.q: How late can I stay for dinner and still get back to Hostel Brikette?
a: The last SITA buses towards Positano vary by month but typically run until around 21:30 in summer. Check the posted timetable when you arrive and aim for the second-to-last service in case one is full. After the final bus, taxis from Praiano to Positano cost €35–€45, so split with travel mates if you linger longer.

seo.description: Food, history, and neighborhoods; day‑trip tips from Positano.

naplesCityGuide.linkLabel: Naples City Guide for Amalfi Coast Travelers
intro: Naples is the gateway to the Amalfi Coast. Spend a day or two exploring historic streets, pizza institutions, and easy side trips.

sections.title: Essential neighbourhoods
body: Walk Spaccanapoli for churches, nativity workshops, and the underground tours beneath San Lorenzo.
Head to the seafront in Chiaia and Castel dell'Ovo for breezy evening strolls.

sections.title: Food & coffee
body: Queue for pizza at Sorbillo or Da Michele (expect 30–45 minutes). Grab sfogliatella and espresso at Gran Caffè Gambrinus.
Try cuoppo fritto (paper cones of fried seafood) for €6–€8 when you need a quick bite.

sections.title: Day-trip staging
body: Use Napoli Centrale for high-speed trains to Rome (1h10) or Pompeii (40 minutes on the Circumvesuviana).
Store luggage at the station (€7 per bag) if you are transiting straight to Positano later.

tips: Carry contactless cards for metro rides and buy a day pass (€5.60) if you plan multiple hops.
Keep valuables in front pockets and use cross-body bags in crowded alleys.

faqs.q: Is Naples safe to explore on foot?

faqs.q: Where can I store luggage?

seo.title: Naples to Positano: step‑by‑step
seo.description: Year‑round route via Sorrento train + SITA bus, where to get off in Positano, and how to walk to Hostel Brikette — plus summer ferry and late‑arrival options.

intro: From Naples Airport or city, reach Positano year‑round by taking a shuttle or Alibus + train to Sorrento, then the SITA bus toward Amalfi. In summer, ferries run when seas are calm. This guide shows exactly where to get off (Chiesa Nuova/Bar Internazionale) and how to walk the final 2–5 minutes to Hostel Brikette.

sections.title: Train + bus (year‑round)
body: Airport → Sorrento: From NAP arrivals, either take the Curreri shuttle to Sorrento (direct, paid on board/online) or ride the Alibus to Napoli Centrale/Garibaldi and connect to the Circumvesuviana train for Sorrento.
At Sorrento: Exit the station and follow signs to the bus stands. Buy SITA tickets at the tabacchi/newsstand (you must have a validated ticket before boarding).

sections.title: Sorrento → Positano by SITA
body: Board the SITA bus signed for Amalfi/Positano. Luggage goes underneath; keep valuables with you. Services are more frequent in summer but can be busy — arrive early and queue.
Ride the coastal road past Priora and Piano; after the village of Montepertuso turnoff, you will descend toward Positano’s upper stops.

sections.title: Get off at ‘Chiesa Nuova’ (Bar Internazionale)
body: For Hostel Brikette, alight at ‘Chiesa Nuova’ outside the café/bar called Bar Internazionale. This is the closest stop to the hostel.
The ride length and number of stops vary with traffic. From the stop, the hostel is roughly 140 m (450 ft) away with minimal stairs.

sections.title: Walk to Hostel Brikette
body: From the Bar Internazionale stop, continue in the same direction the bus was traveling for just over 100 m (330 ft) along Viale Pasitea.
Look for the Hostel Brikette sign on the terrace level. Continue around the bend and take the stairs on the right up to the main door.

sections.title: Ferry (summer)
body: From Naples city, take the Alibus to Molo Beverello, then a ferry to Positano (seasonal; weather‑dependent). Confirm times and fares on the day and avoid the last sailing if you have onward plans.
From the dock in Positano, combine the Interno Positano bus with porters if carrying luggage — see our %LINK:ferryDockToBrikette|dock → hostel route% and %LINK:porterServices|porter guide%.

sections.title: Late arrivals & transfers
body: If you arrive after the last bus/ferry, book a private transfer or plan an overnight near the station in Naples or in Sorrento.
Confirm the drop‑off near your accommodation and ask about luggage handling if needed.

faqs.q: Where do I buy SITA tickets?
a: At tabacchi/newsagents near the stands in Sorrento and at Bar Internazionale in Positano. Buy before boarding and validate on the bus if required.

faqs.q: Which stop is best for the hostel?
a: ‘Chiesa Nuova’ (outside Bar Internazionale). It is the closest stop to Hostel Brikette and avoids long staircases.

faqs.q: How long is the final walk?
a: About 2–5 minutes and roughly 140 m (450 ft) with only a short staircase at the entrance.

seo.title: Path of the Gods from Hostel Brikette
seo.description: Exact route from the hostel to the Sentiero degli Dei trailheads, with transit options and safety tips.

pathOfTheGods.linkLabel: Path of the Gods from Brikette
intro: The Sentiero degli Dei (Path of the Gods) strings together cliff-top terraces, chestnut groves, and sweeping views across the Amalfi Coast. From Hostel Brikette you can reach the trail by combining local ferries and SITA buses without joining a pricey tour.

Three main approaches start from the hostel: sailing to Amalfi and bussing up to Bomerano, riding the bus network the whole way, or skipping the transfers and hiking an out-and-back from Nocelle. Use this overview to decide which detailed route suits your time, budget, and comfort with heights.

sections.title: Highlights at a glance
body: Panoramic balconies float above Positano, Praiano, and Capri, so even short sections reward you with dramatic photo stops.
The gradients are steady rather than technical; confident walkers can tackle the path with good footwear and plenty of water.
Public transport keeps costs low compared with private drivers or guided excursions, letting you splurge on post-hike treats instead.

sections.title: Before you commit
body: Expect exposed ledges, handrail-free staircases, and long drops. Anyone with vertigo should favour the gentler Nocelle out-and-back.
Door-to-door journeys take 3–5 hours depending on your route. Summer heat makes early starts or late afternoon departures essential.

sections.title: Route options from Hostel Brikette
body: [Ferry via Amalfi guide](guide:pathOfTheGodsFerry): walk to Spiaggia Grande, sail to Amalfi, bus uphill to Bomerano, hike to Nocelle, and ride the shuttle back. Longest day but pairs sea views with time in Amalfi.

[Bus via Amalfi guide](guide:pathOfTheGodsBus): buy tickets at Bar Internazionale, take the SITA bus to Amalfi, connect to the Agerola service, then follow the classic Bomerano → Nocelle traverse. Best when seas are rough or ferries are sold out.

[Direct Nocelle loop guide](guide:pathOfTheGodsNocelle): catch the Montepertuso–Nocelle minibus, walk the panoramic out-and-back toward Colle Serra, and return on the same bus. Ideal for a lighter day or to avoid tight transfers.

sections.title: Trail basics
body: The Sentiero degli Dei links Bomerano and Nocelle over roughly 6 kilometres of undulating path with about 200 metres of elevation change.
Waymarks show red-and-white CAI stripes plus wooden "Sentiero" arrows. Surfaces alternate between cobbled steps, packed dirt, and rocky ledges—pack grippy shoes and keep your hands free.

sections.title: Planning tips
body: Check the forecast the night before; rain makes the stone steps slick and strong winds can halt ferries.
Carry at least 1.5 litres of water per person. Refills are limited to cafés in Bomerano, kiosks in Nocelle, and the occasional farmhouse stand.
Validate SITA bus tickets before boarding and keep a spare ticket in your daypack for unexpected detours.

essentials: Comfortable footwear with grip plus sun protection and layers for exposed ridgelines.
Pre-purchased SITA bus tickets (tabacchi or Bar Internazionale) for every leg you plan to ride.
Offline maps or saved directions in case mobile data drops in the ravines.
typicalCosts: SITA bus Positano ⇄ Amalfi/Bomerano/Nocelle: €2–€4 per leg depending on ticket type.
Travelmar or Lucibello ferry Positano ⇄ Amalfi: roughly €12–€16 each way in peak season.
Trail snacks and water from village shops: €3–€8; access to the path itself is free.
tips: Leave before 09:00 in July–August or aim for the golden hours in spring and autumn for cooler temperatures and softer light.
Avoid the 1,700-step descent to Positano unless your knees are fresh—descending Montepertuso stairs after a long hike is brutal.
Use a lightweight daypack and keep trekking poles folded until you reach steeper staircases.

faq.a: Budget 3–5 hours including transport. The ferry route is the longest; the Nocelle out-and-back fits into a half day.

faq.a: Yes, provided you are steady on your feet and comfortable with heights. There are no technical climbs, just steady ascents and descents.

pathOfTheGodsBus.linkLabel: Path of the Gods via Amalfi (bus + hike)
intro: Prefer to stay on wheels? This route takes the SITA bus from Positano to Amalfi and onward to Bomerano before hiking the Path of the Gods back toward Nocelle. It is dependable in rough seas and often the quickest way to reach the full trail.
Buses get busy in peak season, so buy tickets the day before if possible and arrive early at each stop.

sections.title: Buy tickets and plan your timing
body: You need three bus tickets per person: Positano → Amalfi, Amalfi → Bomerano, and Nocelle → Positano. Ask the staff at Bar Internazionale for the best combination (single or integrated).
Check the SITA timetable posted inside the bar or via the Unico Campania app. Aim for a morning departure to avoid queues and midday sun on the trail.
Pack water, snacks, and sun protection—there are no services between Bomerano and Nocelle.

sections.title: Ride from Bar Internazionale to Amalfi
body: Exit the hostel, turn left, and reach Bar Internazionale in about two minutes. Buy tickets, then wait on the opposite side of the road for the Amalfi-bound bus.
Validate your ticket when boarding. The journey takes 45–60 minutes depending on traffic and includes several switchbacks with sweeping sea views.
When you arrive in Amalfi, stay near the same bus bays—you will connect to the Agerola service from there.

sections.title: Pause in Amalfi (optional)
body: If you have a gap before the next bus, wander a short distance into town for coffee or pastries. Return to the terminal at least 10 minutes before departure.
Queue early during summer as the bus fills quickly. The driver may limit boarding once all seats and safe standing room are taken.

sections.title: Bus uphill to Bomerano
body: Board the bus marked “Agerola/Bomerano”. Use your second ticket and keep a hand free to steady yourself on tight curves.
Alight at the Bomerano stop opposite Ristorante Jerla. Cross the road, take the side street to the piazza, then follow signs to the Path of the Gods trailhead.

sections.title: Hike to Nocelle
body: Follow the Sentiero degli Dei signage across terraces and ridges. Allow 2.5–3 hours for the hike with photo stops.
Carry litter out with you and respect private farmland along the path.

sections.title: Navigate Nocelle and reach the bus stop
body: When the trail turns to concrete, you have reached Nocelle. Keep right at the first junction to avoid the long staircase down to Positano.
Walk about 175 metres to the small car park and bus shelter. Arrive early; buses occasionally park just before the stop when the lot is full.

sections.title: Return to Positano
body: Use your final ticket to ride the Nocelle/Montepertuso bus back to Bar Internazionale or Chiesa Nuova.
If you miss the bus, you can walk the road (around 4 km) but be prepared for a sustained downhill with traffic.

body: 07:00 leave hostel → 07:15 bus to Amalfi → 08:10 arrive Amalfi → 08:30 bus to Bomerano → 09:10 start hike → 12:00 arrive Nocelle → 12:30 bus back to Positano.

a: Morning services fill quickly in summer. Arrive early, queue calmly, and be ready to stand. Drivers may refuse boarding once the aisle is full.

a: Yes—allow at least one full bus interval (30–60 minutes) so you have time to explore and still rejoin the queue before the next Agerola departure.

seo.description: Sail from Positano to Amalfi, bus to Bomerano, and hike the Sentiero degli Dei back to Nocelle with ticket advice and timings.

pathOfTheGodsFerry.linkLabel: Path of the Gods via Amalfi (ferry + hike)
intro: This itinerary combines a scenic ferry ride to Amalfi with the classic Bomerano → Nocelle traverse of the Path of the Gods. It is the most complete experience from Hostel Brikette, letting you admire the cliffs from sea level before hiking along them.
Allow a full morning or early afternoon. Ferries sell out in high season, so buy tickets as soon as you reach the harbour and keep a backup bus schedule in case seas turn rough.

sections.title: Before you leave the hostel
body: Pack water, snacks, sunscreen, and layers. There are no services between Bomerano and Nocelle once you leave the villages.
Check the latest ferry timetable (Travelmar or Lucibello) and SITA bus times. Aim for a morning departure to avoid midday heat on the exposed ridgeline.
Carry three SITA bus tickets per person: Amalfi → Bomerano, Nocelle → Positano, and a spare in case of delays.

sections.title: Walk to Positano port and buy bus tickets
body: Exit the hostel, turn left, and walk about 100 metres to Bar Internazionale. Purchase SITA tickets at the tabacchi counter before continuing downhill.

At the beach, turn right to reach the small harbour where the ferry operators have adjacent ticket booths.

sections.title: Secure a ferry to Amalfi
body: Check the boards outside Lucibello and Travelmar for the next sailing. Morning boats typically run every 30–60 minutes in season.
Buy a one-way ticket to Amalfi and keep it handy for boarding; each operator calls passengers a few minutes before departure.
Queues form quickly, so arrive at least 15 minutes before your chosen ferry to guarantee a spot on deck.

sections.title: Ride the ferry and enjoy Amalfi
body: The crossing lasts about 25 minutes. Stand on the starboard side for views back toward Positano and Praiano.
Once you dock, disembark promptly and walk straight ahead to the bus terminal located to the left of the harbour piazza.
If you have time before the bus, explore Amalfi’s cathedral square or grab an espresso—just keep an eye on the bus bay for the Agerola departure.

sections.title: Catch the bus to Bomerano
body: Look for the SITA bus marked “Agerola/Bomerano”. Validate your ticket as you board and sit toward the front for fewer switchbacks.

sections.title: Hike from Bomerano to Nocelle
body: The trail undulates for roughly 6 kilometres. Expect stone steps, narrow ledges, and spectacular balconies overlooking the coast.
Take breaks at marked viewpoints and carry out all rubbish. Respect local farmers and stay on the signed path.
When the dirt path meets the concrete walkway into Nocelle, you have reached the finish.

sections.title: Navigate through Nocelle
body: Follow the paved path into town, keeping right at the first junction to avoid the 1,700-step staircase to Positano.
Walk about 175 metres to the bus stop near the small car park. The kiosk by the church sells cold drinks in season.
Arrive at least 10 minutes early; buses sometimes stop just before the shelter when the parking area is busy.

sections.title: Return to Positano
body: Board the Montepertuso/Nocelle bus back to Positano and disembark at Bar Internazionale or Chiesa Nuova for the shortest walk to the hostel.
If you choose to walk down the road instead, allow 45–60 minutes and stay alert for local traffic on the bends.
Once back in town, reward yourself with a granita or late lunch—the hardest part of the day is done.

steps.name: Return to Positano

faqs.q: Where should I buy transport tickets?
a: Purchase SITA bus tickets at Bar Internazionale before walking downhill, and buy the ferry ticket directly from Lucibello or Travelmar at the harbour kiosks.

faqs.q: How much time should I allow in Amalfi?
a: Check the timetables to see how the ferry arrival and bus departure aligns.

faqs.q: What if the ferry is cancelled?
a: Check conditions at the harbour. If boats stop running, switch to the %LINK:pathOfTheGodsBus|Path of the Gods via Amalfi bus% guide—it follows the same trail once you reach Bomerano.

seo.title: Path of the Gods via Nocelle shuttle
seo.description: Catch the Montepertuso–Nocelle bus for an out-and-back hike on the Sentiero degli Dei, with timings, tips, and return options.

pathOfTheGodsNocelle.linkLabel: Path of the Gods via Nocelle shuttle
intro: Short on time or want to skip multiple transfers? Ride the Montepertuso–Nocelle bus from Hostel Brikette, hike the most panoramic section of the Path of the Gods out-and-back, then return the same way.
This option avoids the ferry and Amalfi connection, making it ideal for calmer days or travellers who prefer a lighter itinerary.

sections.title: Get ready at the hostel
body: Buy two bus tickets per person at Bar Internazionale: Positano → Nocelle and Nocelle → Positano. Staff can advise on the cheapest combination.
Check the latest Montepertuso/Nocelle timetable so you know the last return before sunset.
Pack water, snacks, and layers. The kiosk in Nocelle offers drinks in season, but there are no shops along the trail itself.

sections.title: Ride the bus up to Nocelle
body: Wait outside Bar Internazionale. Buses display “Montepertuso - Nocelle” on the front.
The ride climbs through Montepertuso before terminating at the small car park in Nocelle. Stay on until the bus turns around to head downhill again—that is your stop.
Validate your ticket when boarding and keep it handy for the return.

sections.title: Walk through Nocelle to the trail
body: From the car park, follow the pedestrian stairs down to the main walkway and turn left.
Walk about 175 metres, staying right at the key junction to avoid the staircase descending to Positano.
Continue straight until you reach the Sentiero degli Dei signs and the stone path heading out of town.

sections.title: Hike as far as you like
body: Head toward Colle Serra for the best viewpoints. The full round-trip to Bomerano is about 11.6 km, but you can turn around at any time.
Follow the red-and-white CAI markers, step carefully on exposed ledges, and pause for photos at panoramic balconies.
When you are ready, retrace your steps back to Nocelle.

sections.title: Return to Positano
body: Walk back through Nocelle the same way, turning right at the key junction to reach the bus stop.
Use your return ticket for the bus down to Bar Internazionale or Chiesa Nuova. If buses are full, you can walk the paved road (about 4 km) but allow 45–60 minutes.
Avoid the stairway shortcut unless you intentionally want a long, knee-testing descent that finishes on the opposite side of town.

sections.title: Sample schedule
body: 06:30 bus → 06:50 arrive Nocelle → 3-hour hike → 09:50 return bus → 10:10 arrive Positano (3h40 door to door).
08:30 departure → 08:50 arrive Nocelle → 3h20 hike → 11:50 return bus → 12:10 arrive Positano (4h total).
10:30 departure → 10:50 arrive Nocelle → 3-hour hike → 13:50 return bus → 14:10 arrive Positano (3h40 total).

essentials: Two SITA tickets per person (uphill and downhill) plus a spare.
Water, snacks, sunscreen, and a hat for the exposed ridge.
Comfortable shoes with grip and optional trekking poles for uneven steps.
typicalCosts: Nocelle shuttle tickets: €1.80–€2.40 per leg depending on carnet.
Granita or drinks from the Nocelle kiosk: €3–€5.
Trail access: free.
tips: Aim for early morning departures to enjoy cooler temperatures and quieter paths.
Bring a light jacket—the ridge can be breezy even when Positano feels hot.
Save a celebratory treat at the kiosk near the church for your return.
warnings: Ignore the sign pointing down the stairs to Positano unless you want a strenuous descent that ends far from the hostel.
Buses run less frequently in the afternoon—set an alarm for the last return you can comfortably make.
The trail is exposed; avoid hiking in the hottest part of the day during July and August.

steps.name: Ride to Nocelle
steps.text: Catch the Montepertuso–Nocelle bus and stay on until it turns around at the car park.

steps.name: Reach the trail
steps.text: Follow the pedestrian path through town, keeping right to find the Sentiero degli Dei signs.

steps.name: Hike out-and-back
steps.text: Walk toward Colle Serra, turning around whenever you are ready to return.

steps.name: Return to Positano
steps.text: Retrace your steps to the bus stop and ride back to Bar Internazionale or Chiesa Nuova.

faqs.q: How long should I hike before turning around?
a: Many hikers continue 45–60 minutes toward Colle Serra for the most famous viewpoints, then retrace their steps. Allow more time if you plan to reach Bomerano.

faqs.q: Is the Nocelle bus reliable?
a: Yes, but it runs on a fixed timetable with longer gaps midday. Check the posted schedule at Bar Internazionale and plan a buffer in case the bus is full.

faqs.q: Can I walk down instead of taking the bus?
a: You can descend the paved road in about 45–60 minutes. Avoid the staircase unless you specifically want a workout and are comfortable with thousands of steps.

tips: Carry water and collapsible bowls; heat and stairs tire pets quickly in summer.
Keep pets off church steps and inside cafés only when invited—outdoor terraces are generally pet friendly.

faqs.q: Do vets speak English?
a: Many do, especially in Sorrento and Salerno. Save a list of nearby clinics and emergency numbers before you travel.

faqs.q: Are taxis pet-friendly?
a: Most drivers accept small pets if notified when booking. Bring a blanket to protect seats and offer a tip for the extra cleaning.

faqs.q: Where can I print photos locally?

seo.title: Best beaches in Positano
seo.description: Expanded beach overview covering Positano, Praiano, Furore, Sorrento, Amalfi, and Capri day trips.

intro: Compare Positano's beaches and nearby day-trip coves before you commit to a lounger. This overview highlights prices, free zones, and the overall vibe so you can match the spot to your budget and energy level.
Select any beach name in the table or summaries below to open our detailed guides with directions, food suggestions, and step-by-step access notes.

sections.title: How to choose the right beach
body: Positano offers a mix of free pebbled stretches and organised lidos. Lounger prices range from €15 at smaller clubs to €400 at prestige decks like La Scogliera, so decide early whether you want full service or a free towel spot.
Our comparison table groups beaches by town. Each entry lists starting lounger costs, if a free area exists, and quick pros and cons so you can balance sun hours, crowds, and convenience.

sections.title: Positano beaches at a glance
body: Fornillo stays the hostel favourite thanks to its relaxed vibe, two free sections (one tucked away), and beach clubs such as Pupetto, Grassi, Ferdinando, and La Marinella starting around €15. The climb back up is steep, so many walkers cut across to the main beach and ride the bus uphill — check the %LINK:fornilloBeachGuide|Fornillo beach guide% for operator details and free-zone maps.

Spiaggia Grande delivers the postcard view with Positano's cliffside skyline behind the umbrellas. Expect higher prices: L'Incanto starts near €25, while La Scogliera's VIP decks run €100–€400. A public strip sits in the middle, yet most guests prefer Fornillo's calmer scene — follow our %LINK:positanoMainBeachWalkDown|walking directions% or %LINK:positanoMainBeachBusDown|bus guide% to arrive quickly, then use the %LINK:positanoMainBeachBusBack|return bus tips% if you want to skip the climb back.

Arienzo combines long afternoon sun with a dramatic staircase descent. Packages with loungers, lunch, and boat transfers start near €60 and include access to the club's water taxi—ideal because independent access is challenging. Use the %LINK:arienzoBeachClub|Arienzo Beach Club guide% for shuttle timing and booking tips.

Laurito is a compact cove serviced by Da Adolfo (free loungers with a restaurant tab) and Villa Tre Ville (from €30). Sunshine lasts late into the day, but the only easy access is via their shuttle boats; the public section is tiny. For shuttle details and timing, see the %LINK:lauritoBeachGuide|Laurito Beach guide%.

sections.title: Praiano day-trip options
body: Praiano's Gavitella Beach is a sunset haven with a restaurant terrace ideal for aperitivi and dinner. There is no free zone, and the midday heat reflects off the concrete platforms, so aim for late afternoon. Use the %LINK:gavitellaBeachGuide|Gavitella beach guide% for step-by-step access.

Marina di Praia offers a narrow pebble cove framed by fishing boats and cliffs. A modest free section remains alongside lidos—perfect if you want a change of scenery without losing services. See the %LINK:marinaDiPraiaBeaches|Marina di Praia guide% for transport options.

sections.title: Furore's fjord-style cove
body: Fiordo di Furore is the Amalfi Coast's Instagram classic with a stone bridge overhead and cliff-jumping spots. Entry is free and costs stay low, but space is extremely limited so arrive early or visit outside peak hours. Plan the trip with the %LINK:fiordoDiFuroreBeachGuide|Fiordo di Furore beach guide%.

sections.title: Sorrento's Regina Giovanna Bath
body: Regina Giovanna Bath (Bagni della Regina Giovanna) near Sorrento is a natural swimming hole carved into the cliff. It's free to enter, refreshingly cool, and still under the radar compared with Positano's main beaches—pack water shoes and snacks because there are no facilities. Use the %LINK:reginaGiovannaBath|Regina Giovanna Bath guide% for the approach path.

sections.title: Amalfi town beach clubs
body: Amalfi's main Marina Grande beach is lined with clubs such as Stella Maris, Marina Grande Beach Club, Silver Moon, and Bagni Mar di Cobalto. Expect classic lido setups with waiter service, showers, and views of the Duomo backdrop—reserve ahead in high season to secure front-row loungers.

sections.title: Getting to and from the beach
body: For Fornillo and Spiaggia Grande, start from the hostel and descend via Viale Pasitea. If climbing back feels daunting, continue along the waterfront to the main beach and ride the orange internal bus up to Chiesa Nuova, a short walk from Hostel Brikette. Buy tickets at any Tabacchi/newsagent before you need them.

Arienzo and Laurito run private shuttle boats from Spiaggia Grande; confirm the last return sail before committing to a late aperitif. For Praiano, Furore, Sorrento, or Amalfi, follow the linked guides for transport directions, bus schedules, and ferry options.

seo.title: Positano on a Budget: Practical Guide
seo.description: How to enjoy Positano affordably: transport, cheap eats, free views, budget stays, and money-saving tips.

intro: Stretch your euros by pairing car-free transport, budget eats, and free viewpoints without missing Positano’s highlights.

sections.title: Transport on the cheap
body: Use the Alibus or Curreri shuttle to Sorrento then the SITA bus to Positano; buy bus tickets in blocks from tabacchi to avoid mark-ups.
When seas are calm, mix one ferry leg with buses for comfort—reserve only the segments you need so you don’t overpay.

sections.title: Smart stays
body: Book hostel dorms or shared apartments near Chiesa Nuova to cut porter fees and stair climbs.
Consider bases in Meta or Praiano for longer trips—the commute is 30–40 minutes but rooms are far cheaper in peak season.

sections.title: Food & drink savings
body: Grab panini, sfogliatelle, and espresso from bars instead of sit-down brunch; refill a 1 L (34 oz) bottle at hostel taps before heading out.
Share antipasti, skip cover charges by choosing casual trattorias, and picnic on terraces with deli buys at sunset.

sections.title: Low-cost experiences
body: Plan free hikes like the Path of the Gods (bus to Nocelle) or sunset walks along Via Cristoforo Colombo.
Spend on one standout activity—maybe a shared boat tour or cooking class—and balance the rest with beach days and viewpoints.

tips: Travel in shoulder months (April–May, late September) for lower prices and easier ferry seats.
Track expenses in a notes app; splitting shared costs daily keeps groups aligned.

faqs.q: What daily budget should I plan?
a: €70–€90 covers dorm bed, meals from delis, bus tickets, and one paid activity; add €20–€30 if you prefer private rooms or sunset drinks.

faqs.q: Is tipping expected?
a: Service is included; round up €1–€2 for great service or leave 10% in upscale venues only if you feel the experience warranted it.

sections.title: Transport costs
body: Airport shuttle to Sorrento averages €10–€12; add €2–€3 for the SITA bus to Positano. Ferries between towns range from €8–€20 depending on distance.
Budget €5 (US$5.50) per bus day for local hops; taxis start around €20 for short late-night rides up the hill.

sections.title: Where your stay budget goes
body: Dorm beds at Hostel Brikette hover between €30–€55 depending on season; private rooms start near €110.
Apartments and boutique hotels in town easily cross €200+ per night. Consider Praiano or Sorrento for cheaper self-catering bases.

sections.title: Food & drink
body: Breakfast pastries and coffee cost €4–€6; casual panini lunches land around €8 (US$9).
Dinner at mid-range trattorias averages €20–€30 per person excluding wine; split appetisers to sample more without doubling spend.

sections.title: Activities & extras
body: Boat tours range from €40 small-group sunset sails to €120+ private charters. Budget alternative: ferry-hop to Amalfi and explore for €9.
Allocate €5–€10 for gelato, granita, or busking tips so your daily spend feels generous yet controlled.

tips: Travel in April, May, late September, or October to hit shoulder-season rates while ferries still run frequently.
Use ATMs in Sorrento or Naples for lower withdrawal fees, then split cash into daily envelopes to manage spend.

faqs.q: What is a realistic daily budget?
a: Backpackers can manage on €70–€90 per day covering dorm, meals, and one paid activity. Mid-range comfort sits closer to €140.

faqs.q: Can I pay everything by card?
a: Most restaurants accept cards, but buses, small delis, and souvenir stands often prefer cash. Keep €20 in small notes ready for the day.

seo.title: Positano dining guide: signature dinners & nearby restaurants
seo.description: Curated Amalfi Coast dining picks: sunset boat dinners, farmhouse feasts, and restaurants within minutes of Hostel Brikette.

intro: Our team rounded up favourite restaurants at different budgets, starting with the closest options to Hostel Brikette.
Use this guide to plan sunset splurges, farm-to-table feasts, and quick bites when you want great food without a long hike.

sections.title: Signature dining experiences
body: La Gavitella’s sunset cruise combines a boat ride from Spiaggia Grande with a seafood tasting menu at their Praiano terrace. The package runs about €139 per person and includes the return crossing—plan to arrive early for boarding and soak in the golden-hour views.

La Tagliata sits 3 km uphill in Montepertuso. Either ride the SITA bus toward Nocelle and hop off just after the village or book the restaurant’s shuttle. Expect a generous €65 farmhouse feast with antipasti, handmade pasta, grilled meats, dessert, and flowing house wine.

sections.title: Restaurants near Hostel Brikette
body: C’era Una Volta is almost opposite the hostel on Via Marconi—ideal for €7–€12 takeaway pizzas or a relaxed sit-down meal.
Il Grottino Azzurro sits 160 m away on the same street, flat and easy in two minutes, serving classic Campanian dishes around €35.
Da Gabrisa (260 m away, 52 m downhill) and Next2 (270 m away, 75 m downhill) both elevate dinner with terrace views and set menus near €60.

Da Costantino rewards a short 300 m uphill stroll with window views and hearty portions from roughly €30, while Luna at Villa Magia is a seven-minute, 450 m downhill walk for a special-occasion tasting menu around €100.

sections.title: Worth-the-trip dinners beyond Chiesa Nuova
body: Buca di Bacco anchors the main beach 1 km away (167 m downhill) with polished service and €50 seaside dining—plan your uphill return or book a porter if you overindulge.
Il Ritrovo in Montepertuso and La Taverna del Leone near Laurito both require a SITA bus hop (2.3 km and 4 km from the hostel) but repay the effort with €45–€55 menus and sweeping views.
Standard menus at La Tagliata and La Gavitella run about €50 if you skip the premium packages—still excellent for sharing plates, produce from their own gardens, and panoramas across the coast.

typicalCosts: Sunset cruise and dinner at La Gavitella: about €139 with boat transfer and seafood feast.
Farmhouse feast at La Tagliata: roughly €65 including antipasti, pasta, grilled meats, dessert, and house wine.
Neighbourhood trattorie: takeaway pizza €7–€12 at C’era Una Volta; Il Grottino Azzurro’s plates near €35; Da Gabrisa or Next2 tasting menus around €60.
Destination dinners: €30 at Da Costantino, €45 at La Taverna del Leone, €50 at Buca di Bacco or standard La Tagliata/La Gavitella menus, and €100+ at Luna at Villa Magia.
tips: Reserve terrace tables at least a day ahead—mention you’re at Hostel Brikette so shuttles know where to collect you.
Carry cash or contactless cards for SITA bus tickets to Montepertuso, Nocelle, Laurito, or Praiano, and allow a 20-minute buffer in peak season.
For La Gavitella boat transfers, pack a light layer for the return crossing and confirm the last shuttle before you sit down.
warnings: Expect steep stairways on the way back from seaside dinners—wear secure footwear and pace yourself on the climb home.
Sunset cruise packages and shuttle seats can sell out; book via the restaurant website or concierge before midday, especially in July and August.
Rough seas occasionally pause evening boats to Praiano and Laurito, so keep the SITA bus timetable as a backup route.

faqs.q: Do I need to book La Gavitella’s sunset cruise in advance?
a: Yes—reserve through the restaurant or the Hostel Brikette concierge and request the sunset cruise package (about €139).
Check-in 15 minutes early at Spiaggia Grande so the crew can board everyone calmly before departure.

faqs.q: How do I reach La Tagliata without a car?
a: Take the SITA bus toward Nocelle and step off just after Montepertuso, then follow the signed lane for a five-minute walk.
Alternatively, confirm the complimentary shuttle when you book—tell them your hostel pickup time so they can plan the loop.

faqs.q: Are there affordable places close to Hostel Brikette?
a: C’era Una Volta sits across the road with pizzas from roughly €7–€12 and quick takeaway service.
Il Grottino Azzurro, Da Gabrisa, and Next2 are within five minutes on foot, offering menus from €35 to €60 with sea-view seating.

seo.title: Spiaggia Grande (Positano main beach) guide
seo.description: Free zones, beach clubs, prices, and a simple layout map for Spiaggia Grande — plus how to walk to Fornillo and when to book loungers.

intro: Spiaggia Grande is Positano’s postcard beach: a wide pebble crescent with the clifftop skyline behind the umbrellas and ferries coming and going all day.
Swimming out and returning to shore is unforgettable, but your day on land depends on where you set up — from the central free zone to ultra-premium decks carved into the rocks.

sections.title: Layout and main zones
body: Facing the sea, the public ferry dock and water-taxi pontoons are on the right, the main free strip sits in the middle, and the paid clubs line the rocks on the left.
On the numbered beach map you’ll usually see #1 as the public zone, #2 as the Positano residents’ zone, and #3/#4 as the two paid operators: L’Incanto on the sand and La Scogliera on the raised deck.

sections.title: Free beach section (#1)
body: The widest free section sits between the two clubs. Arrive before 10:00 to claim space near the waterline, and bring a mat or thick towel — the pebbles heat up quickly.
Public showers and toilets are near the ferry-dock entrance. Snacks come from the kiosks behind the beach or takeaway counters at L’Incanto’s Blu Bar (paid separately).

sections.title: Residents’ strip (#2)
body: A fenced zone beside the public area is reserved for Positano residents. Expect lifeguards to check wristbands; visitors should stick to the public strip or rent loungers at the clubs.
If the centre is packed, keep walking along the promenade and follow the signed path toward Fornillo for more breathing room — once you’re on the walkway it’s about five minutes to the next beach.

sections.title: L’Incanto Beach Club (#3)
body: L’Incanto covers most of the sand with rows of orange loungers, showers, changing cabins, and waiter service. In high season, expect roughly €25–€35 per person for a standard setup; front-row upgrades cost more.

Reserve by WhatsApp/email in July–August. In shoulder months, a walk-in before 09:30 is often fine. Blu Bar sits on the promenade and is a convenient way to grab pizza, salads, and aperitivi without leaving your lounger.

sections.title: La Scogliera deck (#4)
body: La Scogliera sits on the rocks at the far left with teak decks, daybeds, and ladders into deep water. Packages start around €100 for back-row loungers and can exceed €400 for panoramic VIP nests with extras included.
Service is white-tablecloth level and the upstairs restaurant looks over the harbour. Staff can help call water taxis if you want to beach-hop toward Laurito or Arienzo for sunset.

sections.title: Walkway to Fornillo
body: To switch beaches without climbing stairs, head to the far end of the harbour where boats load and unload. Keep right and slip through the signed archway onto the coastal path.

Follow the promenade for about five minutes past cafés and viewpoints until you reach Fornillo’s main entrance. Pair the walk with our %LINK:fornilloBeachGuide|Fornillo Beach guide% for club-by-club tips on the quieter side.

tips: From the hostel, it’s a 20–25 minute walk down Viale Pasitea with plenty of viewpoints for photos before you reach Piazza dei Mulini and the Spiaggia Grande promenade.
Prefer wheels? Take the orange Interno bus from Chiesa Nuova and hop off at Sponda or Piazza dei Mulini. Buy €1.50 tickets at Bar Internazionale before boarding.
After a beach day, use our %LINK:positanoMainBeachBusBack|return bus guide% to skip the steep climb back up to the hostel.
warnings: Spiaggia Grande is all pebbles: pack water shoes or sturdy sandals for easier entry.
Front-row loungers sell out days ahead in August — reserve if you need guaranteed shade.
Card machines occasionally go offline; carry cash for kiosks, lounger deposits, and the Interno bus.

faqs.q: Do I need to book L’Incanto or La Scogliera in advance?
a: For L’Incanto, advance booking is essential in late July and August, but walk-ins can work in shoulder season if you arrive early. La Scogliera requires reservations for premium deck beds — message at least a day ahead for the best options.

faqs.q: Are there showers and toilets for the free area?
a: Yes. Public showers are near the ferry dock and municipal toilets sit just behind the promenade. Keep coins handy for turnstiles; private club facilities are for paying guests.

faqs.q: Where can I store luggage before heading to the beach?
a: Drop bags at %LINK:luggageStorage|Positano luggage storage% near Piazza dei Mulini, or use your accommodation’s storage if available. Some premium decks limit bags, so storing bulky luggage first makes the day easier.
