intro: The orange Interno Positano bus links Hostel Brikette with Piazza dei Mulini, a short walk from Spiaggia Grande.
Follow these steps to buy tickets at the tabacchi, ride downhill, and cover the final minutes on foot.

sections.title: Reach the Chiesa Nuova stop
body: Exit the hostel, walk down the front staircase, and turn left along Viale Pasitea.
After roughly 100 metres (330 feet) take the first right-hand corner beside the tabacchi/newsagent — the Chiesa Nuova bus stop sits right outside.
Head inside before boarding to buy Interno Positano tickets in advance; it is cheaper and avoids delays at the door.

sections.title: Ride the Interno Positano bus downhill
body: Board the orange mini-bus marked "Interno Positano". Different vehicle styles run the route, but the destination on the electronic sign stays the same.
Stay on as the bus loops through Positano’s hillside streets and descends toward the town centre.

sections.title: Disembark at Piazza dei Mulini
body: Get off at Piazza dei Mulini, the central stop in the shopping district near the pharmacy.
This is the lowest point in town that vehicles can reach and places you within a few minutes of the waterfront.

sections.title: Walk the final stretch to the beach
body: Walk straight beneath the archway beside the square and follow the promenade toward the port.
Within 3–4 minutes Spiaggia Grande opens on your left — use the %LINK:positanoMainBeachWalkDown|walking guide% if you want every staircase checkpoint.

tips: Buy interno tickets at the tabacchi before you queue; on-board purchases cost a little more and drivers sometimes sell out.
Screenshot the timetable from reception or the digital concierge — late-evening services thin out in shoulder season.
Switch to the %LINK:positanoMainBeachWalkDown|walking route% if you would rather stretch your legs on the way down.

seo.title: Walk back to Hostel Brikette from Spiaggia Grande
seo.description: Follow the hostel's staircase checkpoints for the 30–45 minute return climb.

positanoMainBeachWalkBack.linkLabel: Walk back from Positano's main beach
intro: The return climb from Spiaggia Grande to Hostel Brikette takes roughly 30–45 minutes depending on pace, photo stops, and heat.
These steps mirror the hostel's five checkpoint photos so you can stay on the quickest staircase route the entire way up.

sections.title: Before you climb
body: Refill water and give yourself time for breaks — there are no shops on the staircase until you reach the upper roads.
Grab the reference photos from reception or the digital concierge so you can match points 4 and 5 during the ascent.

sections.title: Step-by-step walk back to the hostel
body: 1. Start on the left-hand side of Spiaggia Grande (facing away from the water) and pass under the archway beside the port.
2. Continue straight through the shopping lane until you reach the open courtyard at map point 5 — confirm the view matches the hostel photo.
3. Take the staircase on your left, follow it uphill as it curves to the right, and climb to the top.
4. Turn right at the top, then immediately take the next staircase heading uphill to reach map point 4.
5. From point 4, turn left onto the road, walk about 10 metres (30 feet), cross over, and take the staircase directly in front of you.
6. Follow the stairs until they meet another road. If you look back, the scene should match the point 3 photo. Cross straight ahead onto the next staircase and keep climbing.
7. When the stairs finish, walk onto the road ahead, turn left, and continue uphill for just over 100 metres (330 feet).
8. Turn right onto the familiar staircase that leads straight back to Hostel Brikette’s main door.

tips: If the climb feels too intense, switch to the %LINK:positanoMainBeachBusBack|bus back to the hostel% once you reach Piazza dei Mulini.
Start the walk before midday or after sunset to dodge the hottest part of the day.
Pause in shaded landings to catch your breath and take photos of the view — you earned them.

seo.title: Walk from Hostel Brikette to Positano's main beach
seo.description: Step-by-step staircase route that reaches Spiaggia Grande in 15–25 minutes.

positanoMainBeachWalkDown.linkLabel: Walk down to Positano's main beach
intro: Walking from Hostel Brikette to Positano's main beach takes about 15–25 minutes depending on pace and photo stops.
Google Maps can route you through slower detours, so use this staircase-first path to reach Spiaggia Grande quickly and match each checkpoint to the hostel's reference photos.

sections.title: Before you go
body: Pick up the laminated staircase photos from reception or the digital concierge so you can confirm the five checkpoints along the way.
Wear sturdy sandals for the pebbled landings and carry water — there are no shops on the stairs until you reach the promenade.

sections.title: Step-by-step walk to Spiaggia Grande
body: 1. Exit Hostel Brikette through the main door and descend the front staircase to Viale Pasitea.
2. Turn left and walk roughly 100 metres (330 feet) along the road to the first right-hand corner beside the tabacchi/newsagent — this is map point 1.
3. Turn right, stay on the downhill lane, and follow the curve until the first bend in the road (map point 2).
4. Leave the road at the bend and continue straight ahead down the staircase in front of you.
5. When the stairs meet another road (map point 3), cross straight ahead and keep descending the next visible staircase.
6. At the base of the stairs, cross the road, turn left for about 10 metres (30 feet), then take the next staircase on your right (map point 4).
7. Follow these stairs, turn left at the landing, and stay on the path until you reach the bottom.
8. Turn right, walk into the courtyard at map point 5, and check the view matches the hostel reference photo.
9. Continue straight beneath the archway, then walk for about 50 metres (160 feet) until the port opens up and Spiaggia Grande appears on your left.

tips: Save the climb for later by pairing this route with the %LINK:positanoMainBeachBusBack|bus back to the hostel% after your beach day.
Compare loungers, free zones, and club prices in the %LINK:positanoBeaches|Positano beaches overview% before you set out.
Share the map via the hostel's QR code or digital concierge if friends are meeting you at the beach.

seo.title: Positano to Pompeii: how to go
seo.description: Step-by-step directions to visit Pompeii from Positano using bus + train or ferry + train (summer).

positanoPompeii.linkLabel: Positano to Pompeii: how to go
intro: Pompeii is vast, dramatic, and easy to overschedule. This plan helps you see the highlights without spending the whole day in transit.
Expect heat, dust, and crowds in summer — carry water, sun protection, and be realistic about how much of the site you can cover.

sections.title: At a glance
body: The sheer scale of Pompeii delivers a wow moment as soon as you step inside; almost the entire city has been excavated and is easy to wander.
It is a low-cost outing if you are happy to self-guide — the historical context comes alive even without a private tour.
Herculaneum is smaller and better preserved, so keep it in mind if you want intact frescoes and mosaics instead of Pompeii’s sprawling streets.
Plan for hot, dusty conditions and lengthy transit when travelling by public transport from Positano.

sections.title: Entry cost and opening hours
body: Ticket prices and opening hours shift seasonally — check the official Parco Archeologico di Pompei website before you set out.
Standard admission is usually in the mid-teens (euros), with last entry ranging from late afternoon to early evening depending on the month.

sections.title: Other facilities
body: Collect the free printed map from the information point beside the ticket booths; it makes navigation far easier inside the ruins.
Audio guides and licensed tour guides are available to hire at the entrance if you prefer commentary.
Refreshment stands exist but can be limited — arrive with plenty of water, especially in the warmer months.
You can store luggage for a fee at Pompeii Scavi station or check it for free just inside the site entrance.

sections.title: Getting there
body: From Positano, ride the SITA bus to Sorrento; buy tickets from the tabacchi or on board and allow about an hour for the journey.
In Sorrento, climb the stairs to the Circumvesuviana platforms and board the local train to ‘Pompei Scavi – Villa dei Misteri’.
Exit the station, turn right, and you will reach the Porta Marina Superiore entrance in under a minute.

sections.title: Self-guided tour
body: At the entrance, head left to the information point for a map and to arrange any luggage storage before buying your tickets at the booths directly ahead.
Once inside, locate Porta Marina Superiore on the map — you will be standing on Via Marina with clear signposts in front of you.
Follow Via Marina towards the amphitheatre, branching off for houses, baths, and forums that interest you before looping back to the main road.
After exploring the amphitheatre, return through the lower half of the site to cover additional highlights without doubling back.
This circuit typically delivers 60–80% of the key sights in far less time than trying to walk every street.

steps.name: Bus to Sorrento
steps.text: Catch the SITA bus from Positano and ride it to Sorrento’s main station (about 60 minutes).

steps.name: Train to Pompeii Scavi
steps.text: Transfer upstairs to the Circumvesuviana platforms and take the train to ‘Pompei Scavi – Villa dei Misteri’.

steps.name: Walk to the entrance
steps.text: Turn right as you leave the station; Porta Marina Superiore is roughly 50 metres ahead on the left.

tips: Grab the free site map before you head through the turnstiles so you can plan detours without backtracking.
Carry plenty of water and refill whenever you spot a fountain — kiosks can have long queues in summer.
Note photo spots or frescoes you want to revisit on the way out; it is easy to miss them in the heat of the day.
warnings: Peak-season queues for the SITA bus and Circumvesuviana can add 20–30 minutes to each leg; build a buffer into your schedule.
Large sections of the site are exposed with little shade, so avoid midday visits if you are sensitive to heat.

faqs.q: Which entrance is best?
a: Porta Marina Superiore beside the Pompei Scavi station is the most convenient for independent visitors — it is metres from the train and close to luggage storage.

faqs.q: Can I explore without a tour guide?
a: Yes. The free official map is detailed, and most major buildings include English/Italian signage. Audio guides and licensed guides are available if you want deeper commentary.

faqs.q: Is there somewhere safe to leave bags?
a: Small bags can be stored at Pompeii Scavi station for a fee, while the site itself offers free cloakroom facilities just inside the entrance.

seo.title: Positano in Winter on a Budget
seo.description: What’s open, how to get around, and ways to enjoy Positano in winter without overspending.

positanoWinterBudget.linkLabel: Positano in Winter on a Budget
intro: Winter in Positano is calm, affordable, and cooler. Use this guide to find what stays open, get around when ferries pause, and plan cosy experiences without overspending.
Pack layers (a lightweight down jacket plus a waterproof shell) and shoes with grip—staircases can be slick after rain.

sections.title: What stays open
body: Core grocery shops, cafés around Piazza dei Mulini, and the hostel bar operate year-round—expect shorter hours but reliable service.
Coast-to-coast ferries mostly pause November–March, yet SITA buses and select private shuttles keep running with reduced timetables.

sections.title: Getting around in winter
body: Use regional trains to Sorrento or Salerno, then the SITA bus; allow 20–30 minutes extra for wet-weather slowdowns.
Carry cash for bus tickets (€2–€3 each way) and bookmark the UnicoCampania app for last-minute changes when storms roll through.

sections.title: Budget-friendly days
body: Schedule museum days in Naples or Salerno on wet forecasts; round-trip train fares hover around €10 (approx. US$11).
Hike the Path of the Gods from Nocelle when skies clear: crisp air, empty viewpoints, and no summer heat.

tips: Choose accommodation with heating and breakfast included so you avoid extra café spend on chilly mornings.
Sunset is earlier (around 16:45 in December)—plan terrace time for late afternoon and pack a warm layer.

faqs.q: Are restaurants open in winter?
a: Yes, but selection narrows. Family-run trattorias and pizzerias stay open weekends; fine dining often reopens around Easter.
Call or message ahead via WhatsApp to confirm hours before you hike down the hill.

faqs.q: How cold does it get?
a: Daytime highs sit around 12–14°C (54–57°F). Nights dip to 8°C (46°F), so bring a warm mid-layer and socks for tiled floors.

faqs.q: Can I get back to Positano after midnight?

seo.title: Regina Giovanna Bath Beach Guide
seo.description: Plan a crowd-free swim at Sorrento's natural pool with bus directions, packing tips, and safety notes.

intro: Bagni della Regina Giovanna is a collapsed sea cave on the Sorrento peninsula where clear water flows into a sheltered natural pool. There are no beach clubs or snack bars here — just limestone cliffs, emerald shallows, and photo-friendly arches.
Use this guide to reach the cove by public bus, pack like a local, and make the most of the swimming ledges before looping back through Sorrento for food.

sections.title: Why Regina Giovanna Bath is worth the detour
body: The Roman villa ruins above the pool frame turquoise water that funnels in from the sea through a natural arch. Arrive early and you can float beneath the cliffs with only a handful of locals for company.

Unlike Positano’s lidos this spot is free year-round. Bring everything you need and be ready to scramble over rocks — the reward is a dramatic swimming hole that photographs beautifully at golden hour.

sections.title: How to ride the bus to the trailhead
body: From Hostel Brikette, ride the SITA bus to Sorrento and connect with local bus line A or C (operated by EAV). Ask for "Capo di Sorrento" or "Regina Giovanna" so the driver knows you plan to hop off near the trailhead.

The stop is about 15 minutes from Sorrento’s station. Follow Via Capo until you see signs for "Bagni della Regina Giovanna" and take the paved lane downhill. Allow 10 minutes to reach the ruins and another five to descend the stone steps into the cove.
Return buses run roughly every 30 minutes until early evening; keep an eye on the posted timetable and plan to be back at the road before sunset.

sections.title: What to pack when there are no services
body: There are no lifeguards, bathrooms, or kiosks on site. Pack water, snacks, and a rubbish bag so you can carry everything back out.
Wear sturdy shoes for the rocky trail and bring water shoes for the slippery ledges. A lightweight towel and dry bag make it easier to keep belongings out of the spray.
In peak summer add sunscreen, a hat, and at least 1.5 litres of water per person — there is little shade once the sun clears the cliffs.

sections.title: Swimming, jumps, and safety notes
body: The pool is deep enough for confident swimmers, but there is no formal ladder. Enter slowly using the natural rock shelves and avoid diving unless you have checked the depth yourself.

Locals sometimes jump from the arch at high tide; only follow their lead if the sea is calm and you are comfortable with the height. Otherwise, float inside the pool and climb over to the sea-facing side for broader views.
After storms the access steps can be slick with algae. Move carefully and consider gloves if you rely on the handrail for balance.

sections.title: Pair the swim with Sorrento staples
body: Pack a picnic or plan a late lunch in Sorrento’s historic centre after your swim. Bar Ruccio at Marina Piccola and Da Emilia along the waterfront both offer casual seafood plates with a view.

If you stay for sunset, give yourself 20 minutes to climb back to the bus stop and catch the ride into town. Trains and ferries back towards Naples and the Amalfi Coast thin out after 20:30, so check onward schedules before you linger.

essentials: Free natural pool carved into the cliffs west of Sorrento — no loungers or restaurants.
Bus + short walk: ride EAV bus A or C to Capo di Sorrento and follow the signed lane downhill.
Rocky access with uneven steps; bring sturdy footwear and carry out all rubbish.
typicalCosts: SITA bus Positano ⇄ Sorrento: €2–€3 per leg depending on ticket type.
EAV local bus to Capo di Sorrento: €1.50 if purchased in advance.
Taxi back to Sorrento (if you miss the bus): €18–€22 for up to four people.
tips: Validate every bus ticket — inspectors are active on the Sorrento routes, especially in summer.
Arrive before 10:00 for calmer water and fewer swimmers on the narrow rock ledges.
Bring a dry bag and clip it to the rocks; there are no lockers or staffed facilities.
warnings: No lifeguards or safety equipment — swim within your comfort zone and keep an eye on the tide.
Limited shade after midday; heat builds quickly on the rocks during July and August.
The path is uneven and slippery when wet; avoid flip-flops and take extra care after rain.

faqs.q: Can I bring food and drinks to the pool?
a: Yes, but there are no bins — pack your own picnic and carry everything out. Frozen water bottles double as ice packs and stay cold for the return bus.

faqs.q: Is there a place to change or use the bathroom?
a: Facilities are limited to the ruins at the top of the trail, which are often closed. Change at your accommodation or use restrooms in Sorrento before boarding the bus.

faqs.q: How long should I plan for the round trip from Positano?
a: Allow about three hours door-to-door: one hour each way for the buses and transfer, plus at least an hour on site. Add extra time if you plan to explore Sorrento afterwards.

sections.title: Stairs & walking routes
body: Map routes with fewer steps (Chiesa Nuova or Sponda) and share loads between a backpack and a light trolley if you have knee concerns.
Pause on terrace walls or use compact trekking poles for longer climbs like the Path of the Gods.

On ferries, keep valuables with you and follow crew instructions when stowing heavier suitcases.

sections.title: Sea & sun
body: Check beach safety flags, wear water shoes on pebble beaches, and reapply reef-safe SPF after every swim.
Hydrate often: carry at least 1 litre (34 oz) per person on hot days and seek shade between midday and 15:00.

sections.title: Belongings & contacts
body: Split cash/cards between bags and use hostel lockers or safes for passports and electronics.
Save emergency numbers (112 general, Coast Guard 1530) and local pharmacy hours offline in case signal drops.

tips: Tell a friend or the hostel desk your planned return time before long hikes and double-check the weather alert level.
Carry a small torch for late-night stairways—some lanes have uneven lighting after midnight.

faqs.q: Is tap water safe to drink?
a: Yes, Positano’s tap water is potable—refill bottles to reduce plastic and stay hydrated.

faqs.q: Are there areas to avoid at night?
a: The town is generally calm, but stick to lit routes and use taxis if you’re returning late from Amalfi, Sorrento, or Naples.

Book trattorias around Via Roma for excellent seafood without Positano price tags.

tips: If you arrive late, overnight in Salerno and catch the first ferry or bus to Positano for smoother transfers.
Use luggage storage near the station (€5–€7 per bag) to explore hands-free between train and ferry.

faqs.q: Are ferries reliable from Salerno?

body: Arrive via Naples or Salerno, explore Spiaggia Grande and Fornillo, and adjust to the stairs with short walks to viewpoints.
Book a shared boat or cooking class for the second evening to anchor the week with a standout experience.

sections.title: Day 3 — Capri loop
body: Catch the 08:30 ferry to Capri, focus on Anacapri in the morning, and return before sunset to avoid last-boat scrambles.

sections.title: Days 4–5 — Amalfi & Ravello + hiking
body: Spend day 4 between Amalfi town and Ravello’s gardens, staying late if a concert tempts you.
Dedicate day 5 to the Path of the Gods or Montepertuso trail; start early, carry 1.5 L (51 oz) of water, and ride the bus back.

sections.title: Days 6–7 — culture & buffer
body: Take a morning train to Pompeii or Salerno for museums, then return for a relaxed final evening in Positano.
Keep the last day as a buffer for weather or pure leisure—repeat a favourite beach or wander artisan shops.

tips: Laundry mid-week keeps bags light; use self-service machines near Chiesa Nuova.
Track ferry updates on operator Instagram accounts during windy spells.

faqs.q: Should I stay in more than one town?
a: Base in Positano for fewer repacks. Add a night in Naples or Salerno only if you have very early trains or flights.

faqs.q: Do I need to pre-book everything?
a: Reserve ferries, boat tours, and headline restaurants. Leave hikes, beach days, and local buses flexible so you can adapt to weather.

tips: Screenshot QR codes and activation details before leaving Wi-Fi so you can reinstall the eSIM if your phone resets.
Keep a portable battery—weak signal areas force phones to boost antennas and drain power faster.

faqs.q: Does coverage reach Capri and Amalfi?
a: Yes, but expect slower speeds offshore; download playlists and maps before boarding ferries.

faqs.q: Are ATMs reliable late at night?

seo.title: Thrifty Souvenir Shopping on the Amalfi Coast

Look for maker signatures or cooperative marks; avoid mass-produced souvenirs that lack glazing quality or smell strongly of chemicals.

sections.title: Where to shop
body: Step one or two streets above Via dei Mulini and the beach to compare boutiques, cooperatives, and artisan workshops.

body: Wrap ceramics in clothes or bubble wrap, and separate plates with cardboard squares or reusable towels.
If you ship from Italy, ask for tracked services and keep receipts; for food items, confirm customs rules for your destination before paying.

sections.title: Price checks & authenticity
body: Scan for the Consorzio or IGP labels on limoncello and look for hand-written price tags rather than only ‘special offer’ boards.
If a deal sounds too cheap, inspect seams and glaze; true artisan work has minor variations, not identical patterns.

faqs.q: Can I bring limoncello or food in my luggage?
a: Liquids over 100 ml must go in checked luggage; declare alcohol when required, and check your home country’s limits on dairy or meat-based goods before buying.

faqs.q: Do shops accept cards?
a: Most do, but small ateliers may prefer cash or have higher minimums—carry some euros in small notes.

faqs.q: Is tax-free shopping available?
a: Yes for purchases above the VAT threshold in a single store; request a tax-free form, get it stamped at departure, and keep receipts handy.

intro: This itinerary starts from Hostel Brikette, guides you up to Santa Maria del Castello, and explains the final push to the summit so you know exactly what to expect before committing.

sections.title: What is the Hike to the Top of the Mountain?
body: A bona fide hike to the highest point on the Amalfi Coast, offering breathtaking views that will take your breath away.

sections.title: Why should you do this hike?
body: The views are absolutely stunning and will leave you in awe.
Completing this hike will give you a real sense of accomplishment.
It is also a great way to get in a good workout.

sections.title: Why should you avoid this hike?
body: If you are not an experienced mountain hiker or otherwise very fit, you may find this hike to be extremely strenuous.
If you have a fear of heights, the exposed sections and steep drops will be very challenging.
If you are starting late in the day during peak summer heat, consider turning back—carrying extra water significantly adds to the strain.

sections.title: Getting to Santa Maria del Castello
body: Follow the [Santa Maria del Castello hike guide](guide:santaMariaDelCastelloHike) directions until you arrive in the village; that climb covers just over one third of the total elevation for the day.
Take a breather in the square, refill water if the bar is open, and check that everyone in your group still feels strong before committing to the exposed upper trail.

sections.title: Directions from Santa Maria to the Mountain Top
body: From the crossroads at the top of the village, turn right up the paved lane until a junction, then turn left and continue past the restaurant until the road bends sharply left.
Leave the road on the right-hand side, following the side path that drops slightly between houses. It will feel like private property at first, but you are still on the right track.
Stay on the mountain trail for an extended stretch until you reach a signed crossroads. Ignore the downhill options and take the steeply rising path.

The ascent quickly zig-zags before easing into a long, flatter traverse along the left-hand side of the mountain face. When you spot stone-cut steps on your right, follow them around the back of the peak for the final push.
Those rock steps lead to the last ramp of the day—keep climbing and you will emerge on the summit plateau with panoramic views in every direction.

essentials: At least 2 litres of water per person plus salty snacks; there are no reliable refills after Santa Maria del Castello.
Solid hiking shoes with grip—sections of the upper trail are rocky, loose, and exposed.
Sun protection and layers for the summit; wind can whip across the ridge even on warm days.
typicalCosts: Trail access is free; budget €5–€10 if you plan to reward yourself with a drink or snack in Santa Maria del Castello.
Return SITA bus tickets or ferry fares if you decide to descend via another village instead of hiking all the way back.
tips: Start at dawn in summer to avoid climbing under peak heat; late autumn and spring afternoons offer softer light without the scorching sun.
Check the forecast for storms—cloud cover can erase the views and wet rock makes the summit steps slippery.
Let someone at the hostel know your plan and expected return time before you set off.
warnings: Skip the hike if you lack mountain experience or strong fitness; the sustained elevation gain is punishing and there are few bailout points.
Avoid the route if heights unsettle you—exposed ledges and steep drops challenge even confident hikers.
Do not attempt the summit during peak summer afternoons when heat and the need to carry extra water add to the strain.

steps.name: Take the rock-cut stairs
steps.text: Climb the stone steps on the right, looping behind the mountain face to the final ramp.

steps.name: Reach the summit
steps.text: Follow the last ascent to the top and enjoy the panorama before retracing your steps to Santa Maria.

faqs.q: Is the trail marked?
a: Markers are sparse beyond Santa Maria; carry an offline map and pay attention to the obvious worn trail and signposts at junctions.

faqs.q: Can I turn back early?
a: Yes. If the upper section feels too exposed, enjoy the views from Santa Maria or the lower switchbacks and return the way you came.

faqs.q: Do ferries operate to Positano year-round?
a: Ferries are seasonal (typically April–October). In winter, buses/taxis are the primary options.

faqs.q: Where can I check real-time ferry schedules?
a: Use operators’ sites (e.g., NLG, Travelmar, Alilauro) or aggregators like DirectFerries during summer.

faqs.q: Which pier should I use in Positano?
a: The main pier is at Spiaggia Grande. Check your ticket for the exact boarding lane on busy days.

faqs.q: How early should I arrive before departure?
a: Arrive 20–30 minutes early; queues are common in peak months (June–September).

faqs.q: Is the walk from the port to Hostel Brikette difficult?
a: It’s an uphill walk with many stairs. Consider a porter service or bus to Chiesa Nuova if carrying heavy bags.

sections.title: Why this route works
body: It is a 120 metre (400 foot) walk from the hostel entrance to the stop, on the main road.
If you are going towards Amalfi, the stop is opposite Bar Internazionale. Queue on the sea-view side of the road.  If you are going towards Sorrento, you'll wait directly outside the bar itself.

sections.title: Tickets and timing
body: Buy a SITA ticket at the tabacchi or inside the bar.  Do not try to board the bus without a ticket, as you will not be able to buy one on the bus itself.  Present your ticket to the driver on boarding.  If you are catching the first bus out, buy your ticket the day before, and come see us at reception to arrange checkout.
Summer buses often fill. Plan accordingly, particularly during the most busy periods.
